Bit 7 Not Used
Failure impact on each lamp is de?ned by WAL_CONF[IDX_ERR] byte :
? bit 0 : if set, the present failure may cause a WAL_1 illumination
? bit 1 : if set, the present failure may cause a WAL_2 illumination
? bit 2 : if set, the failure may cause a MIL illumination when driving cycle counter reaches its maximum
value
? bit 3 : if set, the present failure may cause a MIL blinking
35.26.1 Lamp status determination
� General Information
Variant coding to select emission level impact on MIL lamp
In order to handle several emissions levels regulations (ULEV2 / EU4 / EU5) with one Software Release, each
variant shall be selected by variant coding (tester communication service). Software will behave according
selected variant in view of calibration and functional strategies.
Then, with C_CONF_MIL[NC_NR_VAR_EMI] calibration data de?nition, several variants are de?ned.
Index of C_CONF_MIL[NC_NR_VAR_EMI is de?ned by IDX_VAR_EMI.
Example:
NC_NR_VAR_EMI = 2, two emission variants are de?ned.
IDX_VAR_EMI can have two values depending on chosen variant:
0: emission variant 0 (e.g. EU5) is active
1: emission variant 1 (e.g. EU4) is active
Visualization in INCA development tool:
- C_CONF_MIL[0] , to calibrate C_CONF_MIL for emission variant 0
- C_CONF_MIL[1] , to calibrate C_CONF_MIL for emission variant 1
Management of warning lamps 1 and 2 (WAL)
Behaviors of WAL_1 and WAL_2 are identical. WAL_1 and WAL_2 may be illuminated (state is ON) or not (state
is OFF). When the global lamp inhibition bit is not set (bit 0 of C_CONF_XXX = 0), the lamp is requested to be
illuminated:
? if at least one static failure is present, with bit 0 of WAL_CONF[IDX_ ERR] (for WAL_1) or bit 1 of WAL_
CONF[IDX_ ERR] (for WAL_2) set to 1 and this failure is stored in ERRM failure memory
? or in case of allowed lamp request.
Management of MIL
MIL internal management is based on 3 states:

ERRM, Lamp management

? STATE_MIL = ON (MIL is requested to be continuously on)
? STATE_MIL = MIL_FLL (MIL is requested to blink at 1 Hz frequency)
When the global MIL inhibition bit is not set (bit 0 of C_CONF_MIL[IDX_VAR_EMI] = 0), MIL is requested to be
illuminated (ON):
? if at least one failure has reached its driving cycle maximum value and is unequal to zero (LV_DC_
MAX[IDX_DYN]) with bit 2 of WAL_CONF[IDX_ERR] (for MIL) set to 1 and this failure is stored in ERRM
failure memory
? or in case of allowed lamp request (bit 1 of C_CONF_MIL[IDX_VAR_EMI] = 0)
? or WAL_1 is requested to be illuminated and WAL_1 is linked with MIL lamp
? or WAL_2 is requested to be illuminated and WAL_2 is linked with MIL lamp
When the global MIL inhibition bit is not set (bit 0 of C_CONF_MIL[IDX_VAR_EMI] = 0), the MIL is requested to
be 1 Hz blinking (MIL_FLL):
? if at least one static failure is present with the corresponding bit of WAL_CONF[IDX_ERR] (bit 3) in enable
position and this failure is stored in ERRM failure memory
A special calculation can be enabled for Mis?re A faults with the management of cylinder shut-off (bit 2 of
C_CONF_MIL[IDX_VAR_EMI]):
- bit 2 of C_CONF_MIL[IDX_VAR_EMI] = 0 : when a Mis?re A fault (LV_MIS_STATE_A) is present, the MIL is blink-
ing.
- bit 2 of C_CONF_MIL[IDX_VAR_EMI] = 1 : if Mis?re A fault (LV_MIS_STATE_A) is present with cylinder shut-off, the
MIL is blinking during a calibratable time (C_T_INH_IV_MIS). After this time is elapsed, the MIL is switched on
again.
Important remark: The ?blinking mode? has always priority compared to ?continuous ON mode?. If MIL is
switched ON, any Mis?re A fault shall make the MIL blinking.

35.26.2 Lamp modes
� General Information
Description:
The lamp management is divided in 3 main states.
The pre-drive check mode is used to make a visual diagnosis of warning lamps. Additionally, it can be used to
display readiness status (MIL blinking).
Lamps can be illuminated either by the pre-drive check mode, by a failure, or by an external request.
Depending on NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK con?guration, different behaviors are possible during the pre-drive check
phase.
Pre-drive check behavior in case of stalling event with NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK (bit 0)
Two behaviors are possible:
bit 0 of NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK = 0 Pre-drive check activation between
LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD 1- >0 transition and engine start
bit 0 of NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK = 1 Pre-drive check activation between
LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD 1- >0 transition and engine start, and
between engine stalling event and engine start

Con?guration of MIL blinking for readiness status displaying functionality:
Two behaviors are possible with bit 2 of NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK:
bit 2 of NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK = 0 Readiness status displaying during pre-drive check (MIL blinking) is
disabled
bit 2 of NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK = 1 Readiness status displaying during pre-drive check (MIL blinking) is
enabled
During pre-drive check mode, it is possible to display readiness codes status with the MIL: MIL is blinking if
readiness status is "not complete".
This strategy is part of pre-drive check and does not affect the MIL status (STATE_MIL).

Management of pre-drive check minimum time duration
This requirement is only relevant after engine cranking phase (LV_OBD_ES 1->0).
With C_T_MIN_PRDR_CHK calibration, it is possible to set a minimum time for the pre-drive check duration
independently of engine cranking (LV_OBD_ES 1- >0). Then lamp illumination for pre-drive check is ensured
even in case of quick start.

Management of pre-drive check maximum time duration
This requirement is only relevant after engine cranking phase (LV_OBD_ES = 0).
With LC_T_MAX_PRDR_CHK_ENA calibration, it is possible to limit pre-drive check time duration. If this func-
tionality is activated (LC_T_MAX_PRDR_CHK_ENA = 1) the maximum pre-drive check duration before engine
cranking is C_T_MIL_READY_1 + C_T_MIL_READY_2. Then, pre-drive check phase is automatically ended, before
engine cranking, in case of a long engine stopped phase with ignition key turned on.

LAMP_OFF state
In this state, lamps are switched off. This state is entered at ECU reset or when the ignition key is turned off
and exited toward PREDRIVE_CHECK or NORMAL modes, when ignition key is turned on again. Illumination is
not possible even in case of failure.
PREDRIVE_CHECK state
In this state, the pre-drive check of lamps is activated so as to make a visual diagnosis of lamps. After this
phase, the NORMAL mode is activated if:
- engine is running and pre-drive check minimum time reached
- engine stopped and pre-drive check maximum time reached
In addition, the pre-drive check mode is also used to display readiness status. The MIL is blinking when readi-
ness status is set to "not complete".
NORMAL state
In this state, the pre-drive check is completed. This state is exited when the ignition key is turned off. A new
pre-drive check can be started after engine stalling event, if correct con?guration (NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK) was
adjusted. From this state it?s also possible to enter into LAMP_OFF mode, if ignition key is turned off.

General description:
This part describes the state machine for all three lamps, with m = 0,1 and 2. Depending on m value, XXX shall
be replaced by MIL (m = 0), WAL_1 (m = 1) or WAL_2 (m = 2).
Formula section:
# Part 1: Check transitions and perform initializations at entry into the new
state
LV_STATE_PRDR_TMP = 0
For m = 0 to 2
Case STATE_LAMP[m] equals:
OFF:
If(1) bit 0 of C_CONF_XXX = 0
# Global lamp illumination is not inhibited
and
LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD = 0
Then(1)
If(2) bit 3 of C_CONF_XXX = 0
# Lamp pre-drive check not inhibited
Then(2)
If(3) LV_OBD_ES = 1
Then(3)
# Engine is stopped
STATE_LAMP[m] = PREDRIVE_CHECK
LV_STATE_PRDR_TMP = 1
Else(3)
# Engine is running
If(4) bit 1 of NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK = 1
Then(4)
# Engine running pre-drive check is enabled
STATE_LAMP[m] = PREDRIVE_CHECK
LV_LAMP_PRDR_CHK_ERU = 1
Else(4)
# Engine running pre-drive check is disabled
LV_LAMP_PRDR_CHK_ERU = 0
# Lamp pre-drive is inhibited
STATE_LAMP[m] = NORMAL
# init at LAMP_OFF - -> NORMAL
T_PRDR_CHK[m] = 0

35.26.5 ACTION_ERRM_ClcMilInfo() - private
General Information
LF_MIL_INFO, LF_WAL_1_INFO and LF_WAL_2_INFO contains the information, why the MIL and WAL lamps are
on or blinking.
Some bits of those variables are calculated outside of this private action.
De?nition of LF_MIL_INFO:
bit 0: MIL on due to OBD failure
bit 1: MIL blinking due to OBD failure
bit 2: Pre-drive check active
bit 3: MIL blinking due to readiness code displaying
bit 4: MIL on due to external OBD failure
bit 5: MIL blinking due to external OBD failure
bit 6: MIL on due to OBD Mis?re A failure or NOX failure
bit 7: MIL blinking due to OBD Mis?re A failure
LF_WAL_1_INFO contains the information, why the WAL_1 is on
De?nition of LF_WAL_1_INFO:
bit 0: WAL_1 on due to failure
bit 1: 0 (reserved)
bit 2: Pre-drive check active
bit 3: 0 reserved
bit 4: WAL_1 on due to external request
bit 5: 0 reserved
bit 6: 0 reserved
bit 7: 0 reserved

35.27.2 External request management
� General Information
Note:
In case of NLC_MIL_STAT_EXT_REQ = 0, LF_MIL_REQ_EXT[NC_NR_ECU_EXT_MIL_REQ] is not de?ned and not
updated.
In case of NLC_MIL_STAT_EXT_REQ_FB = 0, LF_MIL_REQ_EXT_FB[NC_NR_ECU_EXT_MIL_REQ_FB] is not de?ned
and not updated.
The purpose of this formula section is to describe external requests to switch ON/OFF lamps.
There are two different strategies for an external MIL request:
1) external MIL request without erasement feedback (NLC_MIL_STAT_EXT_REQ = 1 required)
2) external MIL request with erasement message (NLC_MIL_STAT_EXT_REQ_FB = 1 required)
These two different strategies are important for PID21/4D calculation (for more information see module Statis-
tical Data + AI).
To support both strategies two different interfaces are provided, which have to be triggered by the external
MIL request
LF_MIL_REQ_EXT[NC_NR_ECU_EXT_MIL_REQ] is used for strategy 1).
LF_MIL_REQ_EXT_FB[NC_NR_ECU_EXT_MIL_REQ_FB] is used for strategy 2)
De?nition of LF_MIL_REQ_EXT and LF_MIL_REQ_EXT_FB:
bit 0: MIL on by OBD failure
bit 1: MIL blinking by OBD failure
bit 2...7: reserved
As it is possible to have more than one external control unit for each group, it is possible via con?guration to
choose the number of external control units, which should be supported:

ERRM, Lamp management (Appl. Inc.)
for strategy 1): NC_NR_ECU_EXT_MIL_REQ
for strategy 2): NC_NR_ECU_EXT_MIL_REQ_FB
If a strategy is not used, the con?guration should be set to 0.
Project speci?c information:
If the automatic transmission (TCU1) demands an MIL request, then the malfunction indicator light (MIL) must
be illuminated.
The incoming MIL request form TCU1 (LV_MIL_ON_CAN) is only used, if the respective value is valid. This
is checked by NC_FID_MIL_REQ_TCU1_VLD, which shall be linked to those fail states, which identify general
intercommunication problems or wrong/missing frames with effect on LV_MIL_ON_CAN.
As the TCU1 may sent initial values in the ?rst valid frame after igniton key on or reset event, an additional
timing criteria can be applicated to ensure a robust behavior. Both measures are important to avoid wrong/
virtual transitions of external MIL request, which could result in wrong initialisations of distance/time while MIL
ON (see statistical data module)
Further remark: In case of MIL request from TCU1, an additional trouble code is stored in the ECU failure
memory to indicate the existence of a TCU1 failure to the diagnostic tool (see chapter ?Transmission control
unit diagnosis?).

35.27.4 Connection between lamps and infrastructure
� General Information
Purpose of this module is to make the connection between lamps management data?ow and CAN inter-
system. This strategy controls warning lamps through CAN inter-system. Warning lamps include MIL(Malfunction
Lamp Indicator) and customer speci?c warning lamps 1 and 2 (WAL).
Description:
For VW Diesel projects it is required that the SYS/EPCL is blinking (with 1Hz) in case of failure and that the
SYS/EPCL is continuously on in case of a pre-drive check. The SYS/EPCL is linked to WAL_1 and driven via CAN.
As ERRM does not provide a blinking of WAL_1, the request is calculated here.
To support a freely programmable dashboard LV_WAL_1_COM_DISP is created. This dashboard expects, that in
case of failure the EPCL is continuously on. The pre-drive check is realized by the dashboard itself, therefore it
is not included in LV_WAL_1_COM_DISP.

ERRM, Priority rules
This module is called by the dynamic error management module in case of failure occurrence when the ERRM
failure memory is full.
Con?guration data detailed description:
NLC_OLD_ERR_PRI Set this bit to 1 to give priority to old failure regarding new failure.
Set this bit to 0 to give priority to new failure regarding old failure.
NLC_INC_ERR_PRI Set this bit to 1 to enable increased failure priority.
Set this bit to 0 to disable increased failure priority.
NLC_OBD_ENA_PRI_PERM Set this bit to 1 in order to protect permanent failures within priority
rules algorithm: permanent faults cannot be deleted by priority rules
NLC_OBD_ENA_PRI_PERM = 1 : Permanent faults are protected.
Must be used with US applications.
Set this bit to 0 to apply always priority rules even if failure to be
removed is permanent.
NLC_OBD_ENA_PRI_PERM = 0 : Permanent faults not protected.
When the ERRM memory is full, this action manages failure entry based on priority rules.
Then, based on action result, failure entry is authorized or rejected.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: -
Activation: -
Deactivation: -
Recurrence: -
� Function Description
None treatment speci?ed in this formula section.
35.28.1 ACTION_ERRM_ClcPriorityRules
Criteria to record or not the failure are de?ned hereafter.
When calculation based on priority rules is performed, the result is:
- "storage of new failure not possible" (and "index of failure" = FFH)
or
- ?storage of new failure possible? and "index of failure to delete into the ERRM failure memory)
In case of new failure entry whereas the dynamic memory is full (number of stored failures = NC_NR_ERR_DYN),
different rules are applied:
- A new failure is more important than a disappeared one
- Failure priority as de?ned in PRI_CONF[IDX_ERR];
- Chronological failure order

ERRM, Priority rules
If NLC_OLD_ERR_PRI = 1: old failure has priority on new;
(Failure i older than failure j means failure i has entered ERRM memory before failure j)
If NLC_OLD_ERR_PRI = 0: new failure has priority on old one;
(Failure i newer than failure j means failure i has entered ERRM memory after failure j)
Additional features:
- MIL can never be switched off
- Failure responsible for OBD freeze frame setting (used for OBD diagnostic communication scan tool / Mode
$02 as required OBD freeze frame) cannot be erased.
- When NLC_OBD_ENA_PRI_PERM = 1, permanent faults are protected.
- The ?increased priority? can be enabled with NLC_INC_ERR_PRI con?guration. This priority is a ?nal rule, which
is used, if it?s not possible to enter a failure with any of the other possibilities. Then, it?s possible (only for failures
with priority >= 4) to store the failure, if a con?rmed failure without highest priority (priority <06H), which is
not illuminating the MIL anymore, can be erased instead.
If the new failure entry is not accepted because of the priority, this failure will not be stored in the ERRM
memory but limp home is activated, thus, freeze frame and Data Trouble Code (DTC) are not memorized and
lamps won?t be illuminated by this failure.
Description:
When the ERRM memory is full, this action manages failure entry based on priority rules. Then, based on
action result, failure entry is authorized or rejected.

calibrations, some calibration are de?ned as array. Then, each variant value is accessed by IDX_VAR_EMI.
For C_STATE_READY_CMPL_OBD[NC_NR_VAR_EMI]:
Bit for group YY (e.g. Mis?re) = 1 =>readiness of group YY always indicates "ready"
Bit for group YY (e.g. Mis?re) = 0 =>readiness of group based on individual readiness
information and con?rmed status
OBD II systems must indicate whether or not the vehicle?s ECU?s monitor system has completed testing on
each component. Components that have been tested will be reported as ?Ready?, or ?Complete?, meaning
they have been tested by the OBD II system. The purpose of recording readiness status is to allow inspectors
to determine if the vehicle?s OBD II system has tested all the components and/or systems;

ERRM, Readiness codes
Supported readiness classes are calibrated with C_STATE_READY_OBD. But, the following algorithm is comput-
ing if some OBD diagnostics are contributing to each readiness group. Then, system supported groups are
calculated with STATE_SUPP logical ?eld. It is possible that initial calibration of supported groups may differ
from the system con?guration found when detecting diagnostics belonging to each group.
The readiness status is computed with the calculated supported groups and not with the calibration which is
only used at initialization.

Figure 35.29.3: Description of C_STATE_READY_CMPL_OBD[NC_NR_VAR_EMI]
The readiness code calculation is performed according two ways:
1. Setting of readiness of a speci?c OBD group, depending on the failure IDX_ERR individual readiness infor-
mation LV_READY[IDX_ERR]. E.g. in case of a failure free system only step 1 is used for the readiness code
calculation.
Case some monitors belonging to a given group are declared as continuous by mean of bit 4 of C_ERR_CLAS_
2[IDX_ERR]=1, they are not taken into account for Mode $01 PID $01.
2. Setting of readiness of a speci?c OBD group (e.g. AIR, EVAP), depending on the dynamic Error Management.
If at least one failure IDX_ERR is con?rmed within one OBD group, then the readiness of this group can be set
to ready.
For the readiness code required by CARB only emission relevant failures (bit 4 of WAL_CONF[IDX_ERR] = 1) of
diagnosis activated (bit 7 of C_ABC_INI_TYP[IDX_ERR] = 0 and not deactivated by variant coding mechanism)
are considered.
Rules applied to calculate readiness code for non-continuous OBD diagnostics
Conditions for setting a group to "not supported" are :
- C_STATE_READY_OBD[NC_NR_VAR_EMI] indicates the group is not supported, whatever diagnostics contribut-
ing to it were found and whatever the group is forced to ?complete by C_STATE_READY_CMPL_OBD[NC_NR_
VAR_EMI] or not
- C_STATE_READY_OBD[NC_NR_VAR_EMI] indicates the group is supported, but no diagnostic contributing to it
has been found and group is not forced to ?complete by C_STATE_READY_CMPL_OBD[NC_NR_VAR_EMI]
Conditions for setting a group to "supported" is :
- C_STATE_READY_OBD[NC_NR_VAR_EMI] indicates the group is supported and at least one diagnostic belong-
ing to it has been found or group is forced to ?complete by C_STATE_READY_CMPL_OBD[NC_NR_VAR_EMI]
A not-supported group always shows "completed" (i.e. "ready")
A group forced to ?completed? (i.e. "ready") by activating respective bit of C_STATE_READY_CMPL_OBD[NC_NR_
VAR_EMI] calibration data always shows "completed" (i.e. "ready")

Data computation for SAE J1979 communication interface - service $01 PID $01
A request for this PID returns 4 bytes of data.
The ?rst byte A contains two pieces of information related to MIL illumination status and number of emission-
related powertrain currently ?agged in the ECU.
The second, third, and fourth bytes (B,C and D) give information about the availability and completeness of
certain on-board monitors. Note that test availability signi?ed by set (1) bit; completeness signi?ed by reset (0)
bit.
For communication interface, data transmitted to Scan Tool services $01 are STATE_READY_OBD_1, STATE_
READY_OBD_2 and STATE_SUPP_OBD_2 with the following descriptions.
Bit 0: Misfire monitoring supported 
Bit 1: Fuel system monitoring supported 
Bit 2: Comprehensive component monitoring supported
Bit 3: Gasoline or diesel vehicle (0: gasoline, 1: diesel) 
Bit 4: Misfire monitoring status 
Bit 5: Fuel system monitoring status 
Bit 6: Comprehensive component monitoring status 
Bit 7: reserved

Variant coding to select emission level
In order to handle several emissions levels regulations (ULEV2 / EU4 / EU5) with one Software Release, each
variant shall be selected by variant coding (tester communication service). Software will behave according
selected variant in view of calibration and functional strategies.
Then, with C_STATE_READY_OBD[NC_NR_VAR_EMI] calibration data de?nition, several variants are de?ned. In-
dex of C_STATE_READY_OBD[NC_NR_VAR_EMI] is de?ned by IDX_VAR_EMI.
Example:
NC_NR_VAR_EMI = 2, two emission variants are de?ned.
IDX_VAR_EMI can have two values depending on chosen variant:
0: emission variant 0 (e.g. EU5) is active
1: emission variant 1 (e.g. EU4) is active
Visualization in INCA development tool:
- C_STATE_READY_OBD[0], to calibrate C_STATE_READY_OBD for emission variant 0
- C_STATE_READY_OBD[1], to calibrate C_STATE_READY_OBD for emission variant 1
Development feature
For development purpose, one array is de?ned in order to display one diagnostic per OBD group for which
readiness code is not set to "ready" (i.e. "completed").

Description for SAE J1979 Service $01 PID$41:
The aim of this function is to provide diagnostic (monitor) information related to current driving cycle:
Monitor enable status.
0 : monitor disabled for the rest of this monitoring cycle or not supported.
1 : monitor enabled for this monitoring cycle
Completion status. Status shall be reset to "not completed" upon starting a new driving cycle.
0 : monitor completed this monitoring cycle or not supported.
1 : monitor not completed this monitoring cycle
PID $41 shall be evaluated for all OBD groups which are supported according to the rules for PID $01 (see
above).
If an OBD Group is not supported or calibrated to always indicate "completed", the corresponding PID $41 bits
shall indicate "disabled" and "completed".
PID $41 may be used by vehicle manufacturer for all continuous monitors which are supported.
MonitorEnableStatus:
Each bit of STATE_ENA_OBD_SAE variable contains status for each OBD group as de?ned below. At begin of
driving cycle, each supported OBD group is set to enabled. In case a diagnostics of an OBD group is not able to

� Import actions:
ACTION_ERRM_IncrementDCctr(IN <PRM_IDX_DYN>)
� General Information
This generic module describes Similar Driving Conditions function when NLC_ENA_SCDN = 1
The different states of a failure are managed according the driving cycle and warm-up cycle counters values
(see Dynamic error management core for details).
For Mis?re and Fuel system failures, some additional conditions should be ful?lled to increment and decrement
their driving cycle counter. These additional conditions are related to additional engine conditions and are
called similar conditions.
Similar driving Conditions are :
Engine speed within plus/minus 375 rpm of the original fault occurrence
Engine load within plus/minus 20% of the original fault occurrence
Engine warm-up conditions are identical to original fault occurrence (hot or cold)

ERRM, Similar conditions
Figure 35.30.1: Similar condition window de?nition
When NLC_ENA_FAC_MPI_DI_SCDN = 1 driving condition are enhanced with the MPI/DI injection split factor.
FAC_MFF_MPL_INJ_HOM[idx] is the share of the total amount of fuel injected for one combustion cycle of a
cylinder, whereas the index is the respective injection pulse: [0]: MPI-Pulse
[1]: 1st DI-Pulse
[2]: 2nd DI-Pulse
...
[n]: nth DI-Pulse

ERRM, Similar conditions
Figure 35.30.2: Similar condition window de?nition enhanced with multiple injection split factor
When similar conditions without failure are ful?lled for the failure IDX_ERR already stored in the dynamic mem-
ory in a previous driving cycle, bit 2 of STATE_SCDN[k] is set to 1. That means, that the driving cycle counter
of failure IDX_ERR could be decremented at the end of the driving cycle if the failure IDX_ERR will not get
present till this treatment. If an exceedance is reported by the diagnostic function (bit 5 of STATE_SCDN[k] is
set to 1), the driving cycle counter is not decremented at the end of the DC. Exception: driving cycle counter
decrementing linked with C_CTR_SCDN_EQU_DC_MAX DCs, see description below.
Also the driving cycle counter increment of a failure stored in dynamic memory is controlled by the similar
conditions functionality. Increment done in the error management core is triggered by the ACTION_ERRM_
IncrementDCctr (IDX_DYN) in the following cases:
? Similar conditions are recorded
(bit 0 of STATE_SCDN[k] 0->1).
? A failure already stored in memory occurs again in the following driving cycle (bit 2 of STATE_SCDN[k] =
1).
? A temporary failure or a con?rmed failure with MIL off (LV_DC_MAX[IDX_DYN] = 0) occurs again not in
the following driving cycle but with similar conditions with failure (bit 1 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1).
? A con?rmed failure with MIL on (LV_DC_MAX[IDX_DYN] = 1) occurs again.
In all of these cases, the driving cycle counter is incremented (bit 4 of STATE_SCDN[k] 0?1)
For a temporary failure or con?rmed failure with MIL off (LV_DC_MAX[IDX_DYN] = 0), even if similar conditions
are not recognized during a C_CTR_CDN_EQU_DC_MAX number of driving cycles, the driving cycle counter of
the failure can be decremented after C_CTR_CDN_EQU_DC_MAX driving cycles.
Similar conditions functionality is inhibited when LC_ENA_SCDN = 0.

ERRM, Similar conditions
STATE_SCDN[k]: Similar conditions status for diagnostic instance k
bit 0: 0: SCDN will be recorded (updated) at next failure occurrence
1: SCDN are recorded
bit 1: Recognition of similar conditions with failure detection this DC
bit 2: Recognition of similar condition without failure/exceedance detection this DC
It?s also set after C_CTR_SCDN_EQU_DC_MAX driving cycles
without similar conditions without error
bit 3 Failure IDX_ERR was present last DC
bit 4: Request to increment driving cycle counter of failure IDX_ERR
bit 5 "exceedance" of speci?c limit was reported for failure IDX_ERR
Remarks:
For NLC_ENA_SCDN = 1 (SCDN function used) NC_NR_WIN_SCDN is at least 1
The link between the similar condition instance k and the index of the failure IDX_ERR in static memory is done
by the lookup table NC_IDX_INST_SCDN [NC_NR_WIN_SCDN].
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At RST system event
For k = 0 to (NC_NR_WIN_SCDN-1) do
CTR_SCDN_EQU[k] = 0
CTR_SCDN_SUM[k] = 0
all other output data = restored from NVMY
Endfor
At event NVMINI (saved RAM lost and first ECU power-up)
For k = 0 to (NC_NR_WIN_SCDN-1) do
STATE_SCDN[k] = 0
N_MAX_SCDN_ EQU[k] = 0 [rpm]
N_MIN_SCDN_EQU[k] = 8160 [rpm]
LOAD_MAX_SCDN_EQU[k] = 0 [%]
LOAD_MIN_SCDN_EQU[k] = 99.60937 [%]
If NLC_ENA_FAC_MPI_DI_SCDN = 1
Then
FAC_MPI_DI_MAX_SCDN_EQU[k] = 0
FAC_MPI_DI_MIN_SCDN_EQU[k] = 1.00
# saturation to maximum functional value 1.00 and
# not the maximum value of the range 1.9921875
Endif
CTR_SCDN_EQU_DC[k] = 0
LV_WUP_SCDN_EQU[k] = 0
Endfor
(see ACTION_ERRM_ClcScdnResetDC() for init data at end of driving
cycle)
Activation: -
Deactivation: -
Recurrence: -

35.30.1 Similar Driving Conditions storage and recognition for detected failure performed
last DC
Description:
According regulation the information, if a failure IDX_ERR (using SCDN functionality) was present the last driv-
ing cycle, must be respected to increment the DC counter. In case of a new failure occurrence, if the same
failure was present the last driving cycle, the driving cycle counter must be incremented (if not already incre-
mented this driving cycle) independently of similar conditions.
This information is kept in bit 3 of STATE_SCDN[k] with k = Scdn(IDX_ERR) and calculated at the end of the
driving cycle. See chapter " Calculation of Similar condition at end of driving cycle" (ACTION_ERRM_ClcScdnRe-
setDC ()).
This functionality is performed within the API ACTION_ERRM_ClcScdnResetDC().
35.30.2 ACTION_ERRM_CdnDiagScdnInt
Description:
Ratio calculation to recognize the similar condition without failure.
For the recognition of similar conditions the current engine speed / load conditions are compared with the
recorded similar conditions window. Based on two counters calculated with this algorithm the SCDN recogni-
tion at end of the diagnostic window is done.
CTR_SCDN_EQU[k]: counting the number of times engine speed / load conditions are within the recorded
similar conditions window
CTR_SCDN_SUM[k]: counting the number of times the diagnosis conditions are set
The calculation of the counters is stopped, if an exceedance is reported from diagnostic function.
Formula section:
If(0) LC_ENA_SCDN = 1
# Similar conditions enabled
Then(0)
with k calculated by the table NC_IDX_INST_SCDN[k] = PRM_IDX_ERR
If(1) bit 0 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1
# Similar conditions recorded for failure PRM_IDX_ERR
and
bit 5 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 0
# No exceedance reported from diagnostic function
Then(1)
CTR_SCDN_SUM[k] ++ # Saturation value = 65535
If(2) CTR_SCDN_SUM[k] < 65535
Then(2)
# Check if current N,LOAD_CLC_SAE point is in SCDN window
If(3) N <=N_MAX_SCDN_EQU[k]
and
N >=N_MIN_SCDN_EQU[k]
and
LOAD_CLC_SAE <=LOAD_MAX_SCDN_EQU[k]
and
LOAD_CLC_SAE >=LOAD_MIN_SCDN_EQU[k]
and
((FAC_MFF_MPL_INJ_HOM[0] >= FAC_MPI_DI_MIN_SCDN_EQU[k]

35.30.3 ACTION_ERRM_EndWinScdnInt
Description:
Record and recognition of similar conditions at end of diagnosis window.
The similar conditions are stored for a failure PRM_IDX_ERR (or updated) in the following cases:
- The similar conditions are frozen within the window N/LOAD_MAX/MIN_SCDN_EQU[k], if the corresponding
failure is stored in the memory (failure gets present the ?rst time)
- The similar conditions are stored again (updated) within the window N/LOAD_MAX/MIN_SCDN_EQU[k], if the
corresponding failure occurs again and the driving cycle counter of this failure was 0 before.
In both cases bit 0 of STATE_SCDN[k] is 0 before the storage.
The recognition of similar conditions for detected failure is done by comparing, if the actual N/LOAD point is
within the stored SCDN window. If also the same warmup status is reached at this time, similar conditions with
failure are recognized. This calculation is done at the action call depending of the monitoring function, only in
the following cases:
- Similar conditions are stored in a previous driving cycle (bit 0 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1)
- and the same failure PRM_IDX_ERR was not present the last driving cycle.
In case of same failure present last driving cycle, the driving cycle counter is incremented without asking
for similar conditions.
- and failure is not illuminating the MIL. In case failure is illuminating the MIL at present the driving cycle
counter is set to the maximum without asking for similar conditions.
- and driving cycle counter not already incremented in this driving cycle
If no error is present at the end of the diagnosis window, the ratio (CTR_SCDN_EQU[k] / CTR_SCDN_SUM[k]) is
compared with the threshold C_CTR_SCDN_NOT_ERR_THD[k]. If the threshold and the same warm-up status
are reached at this time, similar conditions without failure are recognized.
This calculation is done at the end of a diagnosis window, only if no failure PRM_IDX_ERR is present in the
following cases:
- Similar conditions are already recorded for failure PRM_IDX_ERR (bit 0 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1) in a previous
driving cycle
- Similar conditions were not already encountered within this driving cycle with no failure
- No exceedance reported from diagnostic function (bit 5 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 0)
- Driving cycle counter was not incremented this driving cycle yet.
This action is called at each end of diagnosis windows if there?s no failure or when the failure gets present or
when an exceedance is recognized by the diagnostic function. This usage of this function depends on the
diagnostic function. It is used for recognition of similar condition with or without failure

ERRM, Similar conditions
According OBD AK LH 5.0, similar conditions shall not be used for fault con?rmation but shall be for fault
healing. With LC_ENA_CFM_WOUT_SCDN = 1 such principle is applied, else encountering of similar conditions
is required to con?rm faults too.
To sum-up, a fault using similar conditions is con?rmed when :
- this fault was detected in two consecutive driving cycles (i.e. "Two in a row")
- LC_ENA_CFM_WOUT_SCDN = 1
Formula section:
If(0) LC_ENA_SCDN = 1 and LV_ERR_MEM[PRM_IDX_ERR] = 1
# Failure is stored in dynamic memory
Then(0)
with k calculated by the table NC_IDX_INST_SCDN[k] = PRM_IDX_ERR
with PRM_IDX_ERR = DIAG_INST(IDX_DYN)
If(1a) PRM_EXC = 1
# Exceedance reported from diagnostic function
Then(1a)
bit 5 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1
Endif(1a)
If(1b) bit 4 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 0
# Request to increment DC counter of failure IDX_ERR not made
and
LV_ERR[PRM_IDX_ERR] = 1
# Failure present
and
LV_END_DIAG[PRM_IDX_ERR] = 1
# Depending on diagnostic type, LV_ERR_XX may be set to 1
# at initialization, therefore LV_END_DIAG_XX = 1 information
# is also required
Then(1b)
If(2) bit 0 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1
# Similar conditions recorded for failure PRM_IDX_ERR
Then(2)
If(3) bit 3 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1
# Failure present the last driving cycle
# Situation named "Two in a row"
or
# Failure is confirmed with MIL on
LV_DC_MAX[IDX_DYN] = 1
or
# OBD AK LH 5.0 : Similar conditions shall
# not be used for fault confirmation.
LC_ENA_CFM_WOUT_SCDN = 1
Then(3)
# Request to increment driving cycle counter
ACTION_ERRM_IncrementDCCtr(PRM_IDX_DYN)
# Request to inc. driving cycle counter done
bit 4 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1
Else(3)
# Recognition of similar conditions with failure
# Check if ratio to recognize SCDN is reached
If(4) N <=N_MAX_SCDN_EQU[k]
and
N >=N_MIN_SCDN_EQU[k]
and
LOAD_CLC_SAE <=LOAD_MAX_SCDN_EQU[k]
and
LOAD_CLC_SAE >= LOAD_MIN_SCDN_EQU[k]
and
((

35.30.4 ACTION_ERRM_DecrementDcctrScdn
Description:
Similar conditions usage to decrement driving cycle counter.
At the end of a driving cycle the driving cycle counter for the failure PRM_IDX_ERR can be decremented if
similar conditions without failure are recognized and no exceedance reported from diagnostic function (bit 5
of STATE_SCDN[k] = 0) (used for mis?re monitoring). For temporary failure or con?rmed failure with MIL off,
even if similar conditions are not recognized during a C_CTR_CDN_EQU_DC_MAX number of driving cycle, the
driving cycle counter of the failure can be decremented after C_CTR_CDN_EQU_DC_MAX driving cycles.
Formula section:
with k calculated by the table NC_IDX_INST_SCDN[k] = PRM_IDX_ERR
with PRM_IDX_ERR = DIAG_INST(IDX_DYN)
DCdec = NO # Decrementing DC counter not possible
If(0) bit 2 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1
# Similar conditions encountered with no failure
and
bit 5 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 0
# No exceedance reported
Then(0)
DCdec = YES
# Decrement of DC counter is possible
Else(0)
If(1) LV_DC_MAX[IDX_DYN] = 0
# Failure is temporary or confirmed with MIL off
Then(1) CTR_SCDN_EQU_DC[k] = CTR_SCDN_EQU_DC[k] - 1
If(2) CTR_SCDN_EQU_DC[k] = 0
Then(2)
bit 2 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1
DCdec = YES

35.30.8 ACTION_ERRM_ClcScdnResetDC
Description:
This action performs similar conditions computations at end of driving cycle.
The following treatments are executed by this action at the end of the driving cycle :
- Calculation of bit 3 of STATE_SCDN[k]
- SCDN storage and recognition for detected failure performed last DC
- Initialization of bit 1, bit 2, bit 4 and bit 5 of STATE_SCDN[k] and CTR_SCDN_EQU/SUM[k]
Formula section:
# Calculation of bit3 of STATE_SCDN[k], SCDN storage and recognition for detected
failure performed last DC
If(0) LC_ENA_SCDN = 1 # Similar conditions enabled
Then(0)
For k = 0 to (NC_NR_WIN_SCDN - 1) do
with NC_IDX_INST_SCDN[k] = IDX_ERR
with IDX_ERR = DIAG_INST(IDX_DYN)
If(1) LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR] = 1
and
LV_ERR_DC[IDX_DYN] = 1 # Failure present in this DC
Then(1)
bit 3 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 1
# Failure present the last driving cycle
CTR_SCDN_EQU_DC[k] = C_CTR_SCDN_EQU_DC_MAX
# Re-initialization of similar conditions counters
Else(1)
bit 3 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 0
# Failure not present the last driving cycle
Endif(1)
# Initialization of STATE_SCDN[k] and counters for ratio calculation
#(CTR_SCDN_EQU[k], CTR_SCDN_SUM[k])
bit 1, bit 2, bit 4, bit 5 of STATE_SCDN[k] = 0
CTR_SCDN_EQU[k] = 0
CTR_SCDN_SUM[k] = 0
EndFor
Endif(0)

� FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
� General information:
This chapter provides an open interface for other module which have link with error management functionality
(communication module for instance). This interface is described with API to provide access to dynamic data
?ow in contrast to static data ?ow accessed directly through variable names.
By calling API, you can access in failure memory data related to Error Management such freeze frame and DTC
stored, readiness code state and so on.
An API can have some input parameters.
Results returns by the API are de?ned as output parameters.
To returns functional results, a software structure (buffer) is used that allows to returns some data with not
?xed size (a list of data for instance).
This structure is de?ned by the parameter in INOUT.
In the output parameter, a ?ag indicate if the software buffer is full or not.
� Description of parameters IN, OUT, INOUT used by API:

The INPUT parameters used by API and their authorised value are de?ned below :
PRM_TypeOfDtc : Type of Dtc
Authorised values for TypeOfDtc are :
? ALL : all the DTC stored in Dynamic memory.
Failures concerned in error management : LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR] = 1
? PRESENT : all the DTC of present failure stored in dynamic memory.
Failures concerned in error management : LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR] = 1
and LV_ERR[IDX_ERR] = 1
? PENDING : all the DTC of pending failure stored in dynamic memory.
Failures concerned in error management : LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR] = 1
and LV_ERR_PND[IDX_DYN] = 1
? CONFIRMED : all the DTC of con?rmed failure stored in dynamic memory.
Failures concerned in error management : LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR] = 1
and LV_ERR_CFM[IDX_DYN] = 1
? DISAPPEARED : all the DTC of disappeared failure stored in dynamic memory.
Failures concerned in error management : LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR] = 1
and LV_ERR_DISA[IDX_DYN] = 1
? MARKED : all DTC of failure marked and stored in dynamic memory.
Failures concerned in error management : LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR] = 1
and LV_ERR_MKD[IDX_DYN] = 1
? NOT MARKED : all DTC of failure not marked and stored in dynamic memory.
Failures concerned in error management : LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR] = 1
and LV_ERR_MKD[IDX_DYN] = 0
? OBD : all DTC related to emission relevant failure.
Failures concerned in error management : LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR] = 1
and a Carb/EOBD failure :
(emission relevant)
bit 4 of WAL_CONF[IDX_ERR] = 1
- PERMANENT : all the DTC of permanent fault memory
Failure concerned in error management : LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = 1
? Logical AND combination between these values.
For instance : PRESENT and CONFIRMED are failure in error management with ?ags : LV_ERR_MEM[IDX_ERR]
= 1 and LV_ERR[IDX_ERR] = 1 and LV_ERR_CFM[IDX_DYN] = 1.
PRM_InfoIdenti?er : Identi?er for the diagnosis related information which is returned by the API (only words
are returned)

35.31.3 API for reading the Freeze Frame
35.31.3.1 Identi?cation of the failure representing the OBD freeze farme
� Description for actions:
ACTION_ERRM_FindFailLawFrf (OUT <PRM_IDX_DYN>) 
The action returns the dynamic index of the failure which currently provides the OBD freeze frame. 
Value of CTR_ERR_DYN_NR is returned if no OBD freeze frame is present 
 
� Description:
For the following calculation, a Law freeze frame class IDX_CLAS_OBD_FRF is used.
IDX_CLAS_OBD_FRF = 0: Law freeze frame set by MIS/FSD failure, con?rmed / emission relevant
IDX_CLAS_OBD_FRF = 1: Law freeze frame set by normal failure (not MIS/FSD), con?rmed / emission relevant
In case NLC_OBD_FRF_PND = 1 also the two following classes are considered
IDX_CLAS_OBD_FRF = 2: Law freeze frame set by MIS/FSD failure, pending / emission relevant
IDX_CLAS_OBD_FRF = 3: Law freeze frame set by normal failure (not MIS/FSD), pending / emission relevant
With the priority IDX_CLAS_OBD_FRF = 0 (highest priority) - >IDX_CLAS_OBD_FRF = 3 (lowest priority). That
means also, that e.g. a failure setting the Law freeze frame with class 2 could not be overwritten by a failure
seeting Law freeze frame with class 3.
Note: with C_ENA_FRF_FUEL_PRI the priority of FUEL diagnostics is selected.
When C_ENA_FRF_FUEL_PRI =
FUEL both sub-groups FUEL_CLC and FUEL_CMPL have the highest pror-
ity for the selection of failure which gives out the freeze frame to Mode $02.
FUEL_CLC : highest priority is given to diagnostics belonging to FUEL_CLC
FUEL_CMPL : highest priority is given to diagnostics belonging to FUEL_CMPL
� Formula section :
# initialization to default values
IDX_CLAS_OBD_FRF = 04h
PRM_IDX_DYN = CTR_ERR_DYN_NR
# ?nd the failure setting the (FIRST) OBD freeze frame

ACTION_ERRM_GetOBDRelevant(IDX_ERR, PRM_LV_OBD_RLV)
with IDX_ERR = DIAG_INST[IDX_DYN]
If(1) PRM_LV_OBD_RLV = 1

35.31.3.2 Request a freeze frame with a certain type by DTC
� Description for actions:
ACTION_ERRM_ReadFrfByDtc ( 
  IN <PRM_TypeOfFF>, 
  IN <PRM_FFIdentifier>, 
  IN <PRM_DtcIdentifier>,  
  IN <PRM_LevelOfDtc>, 
  INOUT <PRM_Frf>, 
  OUT <PRM_ResultFrf>) 
This API returns a freeze frame or a part of freeze frame. With the parameter TypeOfFF, some different part of a 
freeze frame (defined by the law or by the customer - including set or not ) can be returned. 
The parameter FFIdentifier is only used for the Mode02h request of the OBD required FreezeFrame. 
 
The freeze frame can be requested : 
- by DTC 
 * in this case the parameters DtcIdentifier and LevelOfDtc should be fulfilled. 
- for the CARB/EOBD request (mode 02h) 
 * in this case, the parameter DtcIdentifier has to be set to NO_DTC, the parameter TypeOfFF has to be 
 set to LAW) 
 * With the parameter FFIdentifier = FIRST, the freeze frame associated to the oldest Carb failure among 
 highest priority Carb failure is returned. 
 * If NLC_OBD_FRF_MPL = 1 then with the parameter FFIdentifier = SECOND, THIRD, ... also the 
 freeze frames of other OBD relevant failures - in chronological ordering of their storage - are returned 
 * If NLC_OBD_FRF_PND = 0 then only the FF's of confirmed OBD relevant failures are reported for 
 FFIdentifier = FIRST, SECOND, .. ;otherwise also pending OBD relevant failures are considered. 
 * If a requested freeze frame is not available or not supported PRM_ResultFrf = NO_FRF_PRESENT 
See definitions of freeze frame in module ?Environmental data? module in ?Error management? aggregate. 
Parameter Type Hex. Limits Phys. Limits Resol. Unit  
see description at beginning of specification  
 
� Formula section :
1st bit of PRM_ResultFrf = NO_FRF_PRESENT
2nd bit of PRM_ResultFrf = NO_BUFFER_FULL

35.31.5.4 Security mechanism for Error Management lock mechanism
� Description:
A security mechism is de?ned to avoid unwanted locking of the setting of failures in the Error Management by
LV_FMY_ERR_LOCK:
- If API (ACTION_ERRM_lockFailureSetting) is not called within
C_T_FMY_ERR_LOCK x 10 ms to continue the locking phase the locking is removed

35.32.1 ACTION_ERRM_ClcBeforeErrmReset
Description:
This Action shall be used to describe project speci?c calculation to be performed before ERRM global clear-
ing.
With this action, tasks are executed within ACTION_ERRM_ClrInfoByTypeOfDtc( ), directly before ERRM global
clearing.
Application condition:
Initialization: -
Recurrence: -
Activation: At Action call
35.32.1.1 Selective NVMY Data initialization at clearing FMY
General information:
This function allows to simultaneous initialize selected adaptation values, when the FMY is cleared. It?s a combi-
nation of LC_ERR_FMY_CLR and LC_AD_CLR_xx with the possibility to de?ne the adaptation range (the values)
which should be initialized.
important REMARK:
ALL NVMY data of the linked channel will be initialized with every CLR_FMY event!!!
Description:
If the switch LC_NVMY_ERR_AD_CLR = 1 during fault clearing then preselected adaptation values are initialized
simultaneous (additionally to the fault clearing). LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_xx = 1 preselects the adaptation values to
be initialized.
If LC_NVMY_ERR_AD_CLR = 1 and LC_NVMY_ERR_AD_CLR_LIM = 1, then in case of fault clearing the follow-
ing strategy is used:
Here the FMY will be "screened" for failures with readiness code group FSD, LS and LSH. If "no failures with
readiness code group FSD-, LS- or LSH" are present, the preselected adaptation values ( except LC_NVMY_
AD_CLR_EGCP, LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_LACO and LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_CYBL) will be initialized. Otherwise (in case
failure present with readiness group FSD, LS or LSH) all adaptation values preselected by LC_NVMY_AD_
CLR_xx = 1 ( including LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_EGCP, LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_LACO and LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_CYBL) will
be initialized.
Remark: The FMY is cleared by the VAG-Tester, the Scan-Tool (Mode 4) as well as at the transition LC_ERR_FMY_
CLR 0 - ->1.
Formula section:
If(1) LC_NVMY_ERR_AD_CLR = 1
Then(1)
# Begin: Initialize adaptation values ranges
# expect LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_EGCP and LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_LACO,
LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_CYBL
# predefined by LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_xx = 1
For all LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_xx excepted
LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_EGCP, LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_LACO, LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_CYBL
Do
If(2) LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_xx = 1

Then(2)
Initialize adaptation values ranges
like with LC_AD_CLR_xx = 1
Endif(2)
Endfor
# End: Initialize adaptation values ranges
# expected LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_EGCP, LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_LACO,
LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_CYBL
If(2) LC_NVMY_ERR_AD_CLEAR_LIM = 0
Then(2)
i = FFh
Else(2)
i = CTR_ERR_DYN_NR
# Search for failures (LV_ERR_MEM_xx = 1) with
# Readiness code group(Bit 0,1,2,3 of C_ERR_CLAS_2_xx)
# FUEL (1H, 11H), LS (8H, 18H) or LSH (9H, 19H)
While(3) (i > 0 and i < FFh) D o
PRM_IDX_ERR = DIAG_INST[i-1]
ACTION_ERRM_GetReadyClass(PRM_IDX_ERR,PRM_READY_CLAS)
If(4) PRM_READY_CLAS = "FUEL_CLC" (1h)
or
PRM_READY_CLAS = "FUEL_CMPL" (11h)
or
PRM_READY_CLAS = "O2S_CLC" (8h)
or
PRM_READY_CLAS = "O2S_CMPL" (18h)
or
PRM_READY_CLAS = "HTR_CLC" (9h)
or
PRM_READY_CLAS = "HTR_CMPL" (19h)
Then(4)
i = FFh
Else(4)
i = i-1
Endif(4)
Endwhile(3)
Endif(2)
If(2) i = FFh
# failure(s) with Readiness code group FSD, LS or LSH
# are present or LC_NVMY_ERR_AD_CLEAR_LIM = 0
Then(2)
If(3) LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_EGCP = 1
Then(3)
initialize adaptation values ranges like
with LC_AD_CLR_EGCP = 1
Endif(3)
If(3) LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_LACO = 1
Then(3)
initialize adaptation values ranges like
with LC_AD_CLR_LACO = 1
Endif(3)
If(3) LC_NVMY_AD_CLR_CYBL = 1
Then(3)
initialize adaptation values ranges like
with LC_AD_CLR_CYBL = 1
Endif(3)
Endif(2)
Endif(1)
For details of initialization of adaptation values with LC_AD_CLR_xx see spec.
xxF00601 (?Reset of adaptation values") chap. "Table of selective adaptation
ranges"

Execute system event PRECLRFMY

This API shall only be used by special modes like production or transportation mode to clear the symptom
and all related information when this special mode is unset.
PRM_RESULTCLRINFO = INFO_NOT_CLEARED

Endif

ERRM, Diagnostic trouble code management
Different kinds of DTC are de?ned for each failure IDX_ERR:
- one OBD DTC according SAE J2012 de?ned per failure IDX_ERR (refer to C_ERR_DTC_OBD)
- one customer speci?c DTC de?ned per failure IDX_ERR (refer to C_ERR_DTC_CUS)
This DTC could be changed by calibration.
Depending on con?guration NLC_NR_DTC_FMT, it?s also possible to use the customer speci?c DTCs.
For several diagnosis services (e.g. ISO 14229, service 19h), it?s necessary to transmit an additional information
for each failure. These additional information can be de?ned for each failure IDX_ERR (refer to C_ERR_DTC_
INFO) depending on con?guration NLC_DTC_INFO_ENA.
35.33.1 DTC management
� General Information
Con?guration data detailed description:
NLC_NR_DTC_FMT : 0 one OBD DTC according SAE J2012 de?ned per failure IDX_ERR
1 two DTCs, one OBD DTC, according SAE J2012 and one customer speci?c
de?ned per failure IDX_ERR
For NLC_NR_DTC_FMT = 1, the con?guration NLC_ERR_DTC_CONF has the following in?uence:
NLC_ERR_DTC_CONF : 0 OBD DTC is stored in ERR_DTC[IDX_DYN]
1 customer code is stored in ERR_DTC[IDX_DYN]
For NLC_NR_DTC_FMT = 0, always the OBD DTC is stored in ERR_DTC[IDX_DYN] (NLC_ERR_DTC_CONF is un-
used)
NLC_DTC_INFO_ENA : 0 additional information (3rd byte) not available
1 additional information (3 rd byte) available
Description:
The different DTCs for each failure IDX_ERR are de?ned within the following calibration data.
- C_ERR_DTC_OBD[NC_NR_MAX_IDX_ERR] for the OBD DTC,
- C_ERR_DTC_CUS[NC_NR_MAX_IDX_ERR] for the customer speci?c DTC, depending on the con?guration NLC_
NR_DTC_FMT.
a) with NLC_NR_DTC_FMT = 0
? one OBD DTC according SAE J2012 de?ned per failure IDX_ERR
b) with NLC_NR_DTC_FMT = 1
? one OBD DTC according SAE J2012 de?ned per failure IDX_ERR
? one customer speci?c DTC de?ned per failure IDX_ERR
An additional DTC information can be assigned to each failure IDX_ERR by the calibration C_ERR_DTC_INFO[IDX_
ERR], if required (NLC_DTC_INFO_ENA = 1).

Related to UDS,
an other DTC format is ?xed on 3 bytes and used inside related UDS APIs:
Byte 3 Byte 2 Byte 1 Byte 0
00h MSB(C_ERR_DTC_xxx) LSB(C_ERR_DTC_xxx) C_ERR_DTC_INFO
Be careful: NLC_ENA_DTC_INFO must be equal to 1 on order to have the 3rd byte active for UDS
otherwise the 3rd byte (e.g. byte 0) is set to 00h!!
All DTCs are passed on 3 bytes : the alignement will be on 4 bytes (long) please take care for alignment
(little endian and big endian) in case of byte addressing.

the possible DTC formats are:

35.33.6 ACTION_ERRM_GetIdxErrByDtc
Description:
This action is used to return the static index of related DTC (PRM_DTC).
Remark: related API exists on ?rst DTC found and matching to requested format (PRM_DTC_CONF).
The feature around retrigger mechanism (PRM_DTC_RESULT = ?CONTINUE_SCAN? - FFFFh) is used.
Refer to related ?DTC format and storage? chapter for details on DTCs de?nition and location.
Application condition:
Initialization: -
Recurrence: -
Activation: At Action call
Deactivation: -
Formula section:
PRM_IDX_ERR = FFFFH
PRM_DTC_RESULT = ?CONTINUE_SCAN?
If(0) PRM_DTC_SCAN_STATUS = ?START?
Then(0)
# Scanning is starting from the beginning
IDX_SCAN_DTC = 0
Else(0)
If(1) PRM_DTC_SCAN_STATUS = ?CONTINUE?
Then(1)
# Scanning is continued from last position
IDX_SCAN_DTC = IDX_SCAN_DTC - 1
Else(1)
PRM_DTC_RESULT = ?NOT_OK?
Endif(1)
Endif(0)
If(0) PRM_DTC_RESULT <> ?NOT_OK?
Then(0)
For(1) IDX_SCAN = 1 to C_CTR_MAX_IDX_SCAN
ACTION_ERRM_GetDtc (IDX_SCAN_DTC, PRM_DTC_CONF, DTC_CLC)
If(2) DTC_CLC = PRM_DTC
Then(2)
PRM_IDX_ERR = IDX_SCAN_DTC
PRM_DTC_RESULT = ?OK?
Exit For loop
Endif(2)
If(2) IDX_SCAN_DTC = (NC_NR_MAX_IDX_ERR - 1)
Then(2)
PRM_DTC_RESULT = ?NOT_OK?
Exit For loop
Endif(2)
IDX_SCAN_DTC = IDX_SCAN_DTC + 1
Endfor(1)
Endif(0)

35.33.10 ACTION_ERRM_GetDtc - Private action
Description:
This action is used to return the DTC (on 4 bytes) related to a static index accordingly to related con?guration.
Take care for alignment (little endian and big endian) in case of any byte addressing.
Refer to related ?DTC format and storage? chapter for details on DTCs de?nition and location.
Application condition:
Initialization: -
Recurrence: -
Activation: At Action call
Deactivation: -
Formula section:
PRM_DTC = FFFFFFFFh
If(0) PRM_IDX_ERR < NC_NR_MAX_IDX_ERR
Then(0)
Switch (PRM_DTC_CONF)
Case ?SAE_DTC_2_BYTES?:
PRM_DTC = C_ERR_DTC_OBD[PRM_IDX_ERR]
Case ?CUS_DTC_2_BYTES?:
If(1) NLC_NR_DTC_FMT = 1
Then(1)
PRM_DTC = C_ERR_DTC_CUS[PRM_IDX_ERR]
Endif(1)
Case ?SAE_DTC_3_BYTES?:
If(1) NLC_DTC_INFO_ENA = 1
Then(1)
PRM_DTC = C_ERR_DTC_OBD[PRM_IDX_ERR] concatenated
with C_ERR_DTC_INFO[PRM_IDX_ERR]
Endif(1)
Case ?CUS_DTC_3_BYTES?:
If(1) NLC_DTC_INFO_ENA = 1
and
NLC_NR_DTC_FMT = 1
Then(1)
PRM_DTC = C_ERR_DTC_CUS[PRM_IDX_ERR] concatenated
with C_ERR_DTC_INFO[PRM_IDX_ERR]
Endif(1)
Default:
# No DTC existing according to requested format
EndSwitch
Else(0)
PRM_DTC = FFFFFFFFh
Endif(0)

ERRM, History memory
Functional module to used when NLC_OBD_HIS_ENA = 1.
35.34.1 History memory
� General Information
If the functionnality History memory is active (NLC_OBD_HIS_ENA = 1) then NC_NR_ERR_HIS must be differ-
ent than 0.
This module is called by the dynamic error management module just before erasing a failure in the 2nd layer
memory (dynamic memory).
The principle is to copy some data related to this failure in a separate memory, called history memory. So the
failure become historic failure.
Description:
The number of historic failure is limited to a maximum of NC_NR_ERR_HIS. When this maximum number is
reached, each new historic failure entry deletes the oldest historic failure in memory (??rst in ?rst out? princi-
ple).
History memory is de?ned by :
? ERR_HIS_DTC[x] DTC number related to the failure.
with : x = index of failure in history memory
? ERR_HIS[x][y] Data element of history memory.
with : x = index of failure in history memory
y = index of data stored for failure y in history memory
Contents of history memory is the same for each failure and de?ned in History memory
(Appl. Inc.) module.
ERR_HIS_DTC[NC_NR_ERR_HIS] array counts NC_NR_ERR_HIS elements (1... NC_NR_ERR_HIS).
ERR_HIS[NC_NR_ERR_HIS][NC_NR_HIS] array counts NC_NR_ERR_HIS x NC_NR_HIS elements (1... NC_NR_ERR_
HIS, 1...NC_NR_HIS).
The history memory can be read by dedicated diagnosis tool service.
The history memory can be deleted by setting the calibration LC_ERR_FMY_HIS_CLR to 1.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at RST system event
CTR_ERR_HIS_NR = restored from NVMY
ERR_HIS_DTC[NC_NR_ERR_HIS] = restored from NVMY
ERR_HIS[NC_NR_ERR_HIS][NC_NR_HIS] = restored from NVMY
at NVMINI system event (on saved RAM lost and first ECU power-up)
CTR_ERR_HIS_NR = 0
ERR_HIS_DTC[NC_NR_ERR_HIS] = 0 = 0

35.34.2 Clear the History Memory
� General Information
Description:
The history memory can be erased via the application system, by setting the calibration LC_ERR_FMY_HIS_CLR

Recurrence: 1s
� Function Description
If LC_ERR_FMY_HIS_CLR = 1
and LC_ERR_FMY_HIS_CLR n?1 = 0
(LC_ERR_FMY_HIS_CLR 0?1 transition)
Then CTR_ERR_HIS_NR = 0
(complete History Memory is erased)
If NC_NR_ERR_HIS != 0
(at least one failure to be stored in history memory)
For x = 1 to NC_NR_ERR_HIS
ERR_HIS_DTC[x] = 0
If NC_NR_HIS != 0
Then For y = 1 to NC_NR_HIS
ERR_HIS[x][y] = 0
Endfor

� General Information
Any DTC that is commanding MIL on must be logged as a permanent fault code in non-volatile memory. A
Permanent DTC can only be erased by the vehicle?s OBD II system.
Vehicle owners and technicians would not be able to clear or erase permanent fault codes by any generic or
manufacturer speci?c scan tool command (or by disconnecting the battery). Instead, these fault codes would
only be allowed to be self-cleared by the OBD II system itself (ERRM), once the monitor responsible for setting
that fault code has run enough times to con?rm that the fault was no longer present.
The permanent fault code is set as soon as the failure gets the con?rmed status (MIL is switched on).
The permanent fault code is erased after self-healing of the failure, when the MIL goes off.
Subsequent to a clearing of the failure memory (e.g. Mode $04), the permanent fault code is erased if the
diagnostic that caused the permanent fault code to be stored has been fully executed and determined the
malfunction is no longer present and special vehicle operation has been encountered (de?ned by LV_DC_
PERM) such as :
? Cumulated trip length (time since engine start) T_AST_PERM >= 600 s
? Cumulative vehicle operation >= 40 km/h (25mph) for at least 300 s

Subsequent to a clearing of the failure memory (e.g. Mode $04), if the diagnostic detects a pending fault: the
special vehicle operation and the determination that the malfunction is no longer present must be encoun-
tered again once each.
A minimum of four permanent fault codes shall be retained by by the OBD II system (ERRM). But the perma-
nent failure memory may be adjusted over the four elements size thanks to NC_NR_ERR_PERM con?guration
data.
Permanent fault codes may not be erased when ECU is reprogrammed unless the
readiness status for all monitored components is set to ?not complete? in conjunction with the
reprogramming event.
The permanent failure memory structure is de?ned as follow:
Index: IDX_PERM ?[1...NC_NR_ERR_PERM]
- Permanent fault index ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM]
- Permanent fault code LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM]
- Failure is only permanent due ERRM data clearing LV_ERR_CLR[IDX_PERM]
35.36.1 Permanent failure memory
� General Information
The permanent failure memory is a data structure containing NC_NR_ERR_PERM elements.
Permanent faults codes are stored there, with a chronological order, but the clearing is done randomly, because
it is based on the natural failure healing. When the data structure is full, no additional permanent fault code
can be entered, until an empty space is freed within the structure.
The permanent failure memory must retain at least four permanent faults codes.
The storage of permanent failure memory in non volatile memory should be continuous (e.g.: done is a same
channel of non volatile memory). The storage of permanent failure memory in non volatile memory must
be done no later than the end of an ignition cycle (including electronic control unit shutdown) in which the
corresponding con?rmed fault code causing the MIL to be illuminated has been stored. The details of storage
depend on the respective NVMY implementation and are described in speci?c module.
Consistency check
A fault is declared permanent and reported to scan tool using mode $0A only when the permanent fault has
been stored into NVMY.
Due to unexpected battery disconnection (during power-latch phase) it may appear some inconsistency be-
tween permanent memory and dynamic memory (example: Fault A is permanent and stored into NVMY but
MIL is OFF and fault is neither con?rmed nor pending). In such case, to prevent permanent faults from be-
coming non-erasable due to the sudden battery disconnection between permanent data storage and general
storage of all other ERRM data, a consistency check is introduced to check incoherencies. If such situation is
detected, all permanent faults are marked in order to ease their self healing in a subsequent cycle, if following
conditions are gathered:
- diagnosis has run long enough to detect a possible malfunction and malfunction not present
- minimum trip (permanent fault cycle) has been detected
Case the diagnostic failed, marked fault will be un-marked and logged again as permanent.

ERRM, Permanent fault code
Reloading process
In addition to the consistency check between NVMY data and RAM memories, a regular reloading of faults is
launched at each ECU reset and end of driving cycles.
Principle: this robustness mechanism checks for newly empty spaces created into permanent memory (natu-
ral healing of permanent faults) and forces failure entry into permanent failure memory of faults which could
not be logged earlier because the permanent memory was full at fault detection,
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At NVMINI system event
CTR_ERR_PERM_NR = 0
For IDX_PERM = 1 to NC_NR_ERR_PERM
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = 0
ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = FFFFh # NO_ERROR
ERR_PERM_SAVE[IDX_PERM] = FFFFh # NO_ERROR
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_CLR[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = 0
Endfor
At NVMRES system event
For IDX_PERM = 1 to NC_NR_ERR_PERM
ERR_PERM_SAVE[IDX_PERM] = ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM]
Endfor
At RST system event
# Consistency check
If(1) LV_NVMY_WRG_PERM_DYN = 1
Then(1)
# Inconsistent data detected during NVMY restore
# All permanent faults are marked
ACTION_ERRM_ClcPermanentIniErrm
Else(1)
# Data were found coherent
No treatment
Endif(1)
# Reloading mechanism shall be executed
# after data were restored from NVMY
# Check for other confirmed failures requesting MIL
# On which could enter into newly empty space created
# into permanent failure memory
For(1) k = 0 to (CTR_ERR_DYN_NR - 1)
IDX_ERR = DIAG_INST[k]
ACTION_ERRM_GetMilRelevant (IDX_ERR, PRM_LV_MIL_RLV)
If(2) LV_DC_MAX[k] = 1
and
PRM_LV_MIL_RLV = 1 # Failure is MIL relevant
Then(2)
# Fault is stored as permanent.
# If it was marked due to Mode $04
# or inconsistency detection, it is un-marked
ACTION_ERRM_StorePermanentCode(IDX_ERR)
Endif(2)
EndFor(1)

35.36.3 Standardized vehicle operation for permanent fault code erasing after Mode
$04
� General Information
A special driving cycle (LV_DC_PERM) for permanent fault code clearing after Mode $04 is de?ned, which is
set, if the following standardized vehicle operations are ful?lled:
? Cumulated trip length (time since engine start) T_AST_PERM >= C_T_AST_PERM
(CARB : 600 s)
? Cumulative vehicle operation >= C_VS_THD_PERM for minimum of C_T_VS_PERM
(CARB : >= 40 km/h (25 mph) for at least 300 s)
? Continuous vehicle operation in idle equal or longer than C_T_IS_PERM (accelerator pedal released and
vehicle speed less or equal than 1 mph)
(CARB : 30 s)
whatever
? altitude condition is (no criteria for ambient pressure is de?ned)
? ambient temperature is (no criteria on ambient temperature is de?ned)

If(4) LV_ERR_PND[IDX_DYN] = 0
Then(4)
# failure healing for failures using SCDN or not
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[IDX_PERM] = 1
Else(4)
# Need to be met again for erasing
permanent fault code
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = 0
Endif(4)
Else(3)
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[IDX_PERM] = 1
Endif(3)
Endif(2a)
If(2b)(LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = 1
and
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[IDX_PERM] = 1)
Then(2b)
# No failure and diagnostic done and a special
driving cycle for permanent fault code are
satisfied sincelast ERRM clearing or pending
failure: Permanent failure may be cleared
ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = FFFFh # NO_ERROR
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_CLR[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = 0
# Permanent failure counter is decreased
If(4) CTR_ERR_PERM_NR > 0
Then(4)
CTR_ERR_PERM_NR = CTR_ERR_PERM_NR - 1
Else(4)
CTR_ERR_PERM_NR = 0
Endif(4)
Endif(2b)
Endif(1)
Endfor
# Permanent failure memory sorting to remove empty spaces - "heapsorting"
For IDX_PERM = 1 to (NC_NR_ERR_PERM-1)
If(1) ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = FFFFh # NO_ERROR
Then(1)
For k = (IDX_PERM + 1) to NC_NR_ERR_PERM
If(2) ERR_PERM[k] <> FFFFh # NO_ERROR
Then(2)
# Swapping
ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = ERR_PERM[k]
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[IDX_PERM] =
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[k]
LV_ERR_CLR[IDX_PERM] = LV_ERR_CLR[k]
LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = LV_ERR_PERM[k]
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = LV_DC_PERM_MEM[k]
# Clearing of swapped data
ERR_PERM[k] = FFFFh # NO_ERROR
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[k] = 0
LV_ERR_CLR[k] = 0
LV_ERR_PERM[k] = 0
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[k] = 0
Exit For loop
Endif(2)
Endfor

35.36.6 ACTION_ERRM_StorePermanentCode
Description:
Storage of permanent fault code
This action shall be called in order to store a permanent fault code.
When permanent memory is full, the permanent code storage is postponed until a free space within memory
is released. Permanent codes are stored according the chronological appearance order.
Formula section:
For IDX_PERM = 1 to NC_NR_ERR_PERM
If(1) ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = PRM_IDX_ERR
Then(1)
# Permanent failure related to PRM_IDX_ERR is already stored.
# If failure was only permanent due to a previous ERRM data
# clearing, this information is cleared to avoid permanent
# clearing at end of driving cycle
LV_ERR_CLR[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = 1
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = 0
Exit for loop
Else(1)
If(2) CTR_ERR_PERM_NR <> NC_NR_ERR_PERM
Then(2)
# Permanent failure memory is not full
If(3) LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = 0
Then(3)
# Empty area detected
ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = PRM_IDX_ERR
LV_ERR_CLR[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = 1
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = 0
If(4) CTR_ERR_PERM_NR < NC_NR_ERR_PERM
Then(4)
CTR_ERR_PERM_NR = CTR_ERR_PERM_NR + 1
Else(4)
CTR_ERR_PERM_NR = NC_NR_ERR_PERM
Endif(4)
Exit for loop

# A permanent failure is already logged at
# this position
Endif(3)
Else(2)
# Permanent failure memory is full. PRM_IDX_ERR failure
can not be stored as permanent until a free space is
released

35.36.7 ACTION_ERRM_ErasePermanentCode
Description:
Erasing permanent fault code (self-clearing)
This action shall be called to erase a permanent fault code from memory. A permanent fault code is always
self cleared. None external action can affect or delete this code.
Formula section:
# Erasing permanent fault code
For(0) IDX_PERM = 1 to NC_NR_ERR_PERM do
If(1) ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = PRM_IDX_ERR
Then(1)
# PRM_IDX_ERR error to be cleared has been found
ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = FFFFh # NO_ERROR
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_CLR[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = 0
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = 0
If(2) CTR_ERR_PERM_NR > 0
Then(2)
CTR_ERR_PERM_NR = CTR_ERR_PERM_NR - 1
Else(2)
CTR_ERR_PERM_NR = 0
Endif(2)
# Newly created empty place has IDX_PERM index value
Exit For loop(0)
Endif(1)
Endfor(0)
# Permanent failure memory sorting to remove empty space generated above
If(1) IDX_PERM <> NC_NR_ERR_PERM
Then(1)
For k = IDX_PERM to (NC_NR_ERR_PERM-1) do
ERR_PERM[k] = ERR_PERM[k+1]
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[k] = LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[k+1]
LV_ERR_CLR[k] = LV_ERR_CLR[k+1]
LV_ERR_PERM[k] = LV_ERR_PERM[k+1]
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[k] = LV_DC_PERM_MEM[k+1]
Endfor
ERR_PERM[NC_NR_ERR_PERM] = FFFFh # NO_ERROR
LV_DC_WOUT_ERR_LST_CLR_PND[NC_NR_ERR_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_CLR[NC_NR_ERR_PERM] = 0
LV_ERR_PERM[NC_NR_ERR_PERM] = 0
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[NC_NR_ERR_PERM] = 0
Endif(1)

35.36.8 ACTION_ERRM_ClcPermanentIniErrm
Description:
Impact of error management data clearing inside permanent memory
This action is called when all error management data is cleared (e.g. Mode $04 executed by scan tool).
After an overall data clearing of error management data, permanent errors are marked in order to allow a self
clearing at the end of next driving cycle, if the following conditions are gathered:
- diagnosis has run long enough to detect a possible malfunction
- malfunction not present
Formula section:
ACTION_ERRM_ClcPermanentSetDC
For(0) IDX_PERM = 1 to NC_NR_ERR_PERM
If(1) LV_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = 1
Then(1)
# A permanent fault code is stored at IDX_PERM position
LV_ERR_CLR[IDX_PERM] = 1
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = 0
Else(1)
# No permanent fault code stored as from position
IDX_PERM until end
Exit For loop(0)
Endif(1)
Endfor(0)

35.36.9 ACTION_ERRM_ClcPermanentByErr
Description:
Impact of failure clearing (with diagnostic tool) inside permanent memory
This action is called when one unique failure is cleared by a diagnostic tool. After clearing of any individual
failure, the related permanent code is marked to allow a self clearing at the end of next driving cycle, if the
following condition are gathered:
- diagnosis has run long enough to detect a possible malfunction
- malfunction not present
Formula section:
ACTION_ERRM_ClcPermanentSetDC
For IDX_PERM = 1 to NC_NR_ERR_PERM
If(1) ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = PRM_IDX_ERR
Then(1)
LV_ERR_CLR[IDX_PERM] = 1
LV_DC_PERM_MEM[IDX_PERM] = 0
Exit For loop
Endif(1)
Endfor

ACTION_ERRM_ClcPermanentInh() Mode: O
This action is called at the beginning of driving cycle or ERRM data clearing.
� Import actions:
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN <PRM_FID>, OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS>)
� General Information
This speci?cation is used to implement speci?c requirements or make some adaptations to project context.
Inhibition of standardized vehicle operation operation for permanent fault code erasing after Mode $04
With the value LV_INH_DC_PERM the inhibition of the standardized vehicle operation calculation for permanent
fault code erasing after Mode $04 is controlled. The OBD II system shall disable it if a malfunction of any
component used to determine if the following criteria are satis?ed (i.e., vehicle speed, idle operation, time of
operation, ...) has been detected. Calculations shall resume as soon as the malfunction is no longer present.
Criteria required to set LV_DC_PERM (standardized vehicle operation for permanent code )
? Cumulated trip length (time since engine start) T_AST_PERM >= C_T_AST_RBM
(CARB : 600 s)
? Cumulative vehicle operation >= C_VS_THD_RBM for minimum of C_T_VS_RBM
(CARB : >= 40 km/h (25mph) for at least 300 s)
? Continuous vehicle operation in idle equal or longer than C_T_IS_RBM (accelerator pedal released and
vehicle speed less or equal than 1 mph)
(CARB : 30 s)
whatever
? altitude condition is (no criteria for ambient pressure is de?ned)

This module describes the interfaces to retrieve all information of a DTC. For example, its status byte, the
number of DTC matching to the status mask, the next DTC matching to a status mask etc.

ERRM, UDS communication interface
Be careful: NLC_ENA_DTC_INFO must be equal to 1 on order to have the 3rd byte active for UDS otherwise the
3rd byte is set to 00h !!
All DTCs are passed on 3 bytes : the alignement will be on 4 bytes (long) please take care for alignment
(little endian and big endian) in case of byte addressing.
For the APIs GetNextDTC and GetNextPermDTC, the consumer must take care that the number of calls
must be exactly the DTCNr returned by the API GetNumberOfDTC.
All produced data inside these APIs have to be initialized (even if they are not updated inside some functional
branches - due to algorithm constraints).
Overview
The communication between ERRM and DGNC is done by unitary APIs and without shared buffer. The status
byte is claculated at each time of the request. When the API GetNumberOf DTC is called, the status byte of
each static failure is freezed inside a table if status byte is matching to the status mask otherwise it?s forced
to FFh. Then when the API is called to get the next DTC, this table is parsed and each DTC is returned with its
status byte.
An API is also available to calculate independently the status byte of a DTC. The calculation of the status byte
is done in Appl. Inc. to be adapted by the project if needed.

Subservice 01h (reportNumberOfDTCByStatusMask)
This service is calling ACTION_ERRM_GetNumberOfDTC. This action is re-triggable and returns its status
: OK, NOT_OK, CONTINUE_SCAN. Fist call should be with FIRST parameter and subsequent must be with
CONTINUE parameter. In between, before P2can max timeout is reached a 78h response should be sent by
DGNC module.
Subservice 02h (reportDTCByStatusMask)
This service is calling ACTION_ERRM_GetNumberOfDTC. This action is re-triggable and returns its status
: OK, NOT_OK, CONTINUE_SCAN. Fist call should be with FIRST parameter and subsequent must be with
CONTINUE parameter. In between, before P2can max timeout is reached a 78h response should be sent by
DGNC module.
Then, when counting is ?nished. The ACTION_ERRM_GetNextDTC is called with FIRST_DTC parameter
and then re-called with NEXT_DTC. Be careful this call shoulb exactly equal to the number of DTCs returned by
the ACTION_ERRM_GetNumberOfDTC.
This reports each DTC and its statusByte ?tting to the StatusMask.
Subservice 06h (reportDTCExtendedDataRecordByDTCNumber)
This service is made in generic but must be adpated to project needs.
Subservice 07h (reportNumberOfDTCBySeverityMask)
This service is calling ACTION_ERRM_GetNumOfDTCBySevMsk. This action is re-triggable and returns
its status : OK, NOT_OK, CONTINUE_SCAN. Fist call should be with FIRST parameter and subsequent must be
with CONTINUE parameter. In between, before P2can max timeout is reached a 78h response should be sent
by DGNC module.
Subservice 08h (reportDTCBySeverityMask)
This service is calling ACTION_ERRM_GetNumberOfDTC. This action is re-triggable and returns its status
: OK, NOT_OK, CONTINUE_SCAN. Fist call should be with FIRST parameter and subsequent must be with
CONTINUE parameter. In between, before P2can max timeout is reached a 78h response should be sent by
DGNC module.
Then, when counting is ?nished. The ACTION_ERRM_GetNextDTC is called with FIRST_DTC parameter
and then re-called with NEXT_DTC. Be careful this call shoulb exactly equal to the number of DTCs returned by
the ACTION_ERRM_GetNumberOfDTC.
This reports each DTC and its severity information.
Subservice 09h (reportSeverityInformationOfDTC)
This service is calling ACTION_ERRMGetSevMskOfDTC. This action is re-triggable and returns its status
: OK, NOT_OK, CONTINUE_SCAN. Fist call should be with FIRST parameter and subsequent must be with
CONTINUE parameter. In between, before P2can max timeout is reached a 78h response should be sent by
DGNC module.
This reports the DTC (if found) and its severity information.

This service is calling ACTION_ERRM_GetNumbOfSuppDTC. This returns the number of DTC actually
supported. Then the ACTION_ERRM_GetNextSuppDTC is called with FIRST_DTC parameter and then re-called
with NEXT_DTC. Be careful this call shoulb exactly equal to the number of DTCs returned by the ACTION_

Subservice 0Ch (reportFirstCon?rmedDTC)

status byte.
Subservice 0Eh (reportMostRecentCon?rmedDTC)
This service is calling ACTION_ERRM_GetMostRecCfmDTC. This action returns the most recent con?rmed
DTC and its status byte.
Subservice 12h (reportNumberOfEmmissionRelatedOBDDTCByStatusMask)
This service has the same mechanism than 19 01h. The only difference is that the parameter DTCType
should be OBD instead of ALL.
Subservice 13h (reportEmmissionRelatedOBDDTCByStatusMask)
This service has the same mechanism than 19 02h. The only difference is that the parameter DTCType
should be OBD instead of ALL.
Subservice 15h (reportDTCWithPermanentStatus)
This service is calling the ACTION_GetNumberOfPermDTC. This returns the number of DTC actually
supported. Then the ACTION_ERRM_GetNextPermDTC is called with FIRST_DTC parameter and then re-called
with NEXT_DTC. Be careful this call shoulb exactly equal to the number of DTCs returned by the ACTION_
ERRM_GetNumbOfPermDTC. This returns each supported DTC and its statusByte.
=>Service 85h
This service is designed to control the DTC entry in error management. With this service, all the DTCs
which are logged during the diagnostic session are marked and removed when the session ends.

bit number meaning Formula section
bit 0 TestFail See de?nition of action ACTION_ERRM_GetDTCStatusByte
bit 1 TestFailThisOperationCycle See de?nition of action ACTION_ERRM_GetDTCStatusByte
bit 2 PendingDTC See de?nition of action ACTION_ERRM_GetDTCStatusByte
bit 3 Con?rmedDTC See de?nition of action ACTION_ERRM_GetDTCStatusByte
bit 4 TestNotCompletedSinceLastClear See de?nition of action ACTION_ERRM_GetDTCStatusByte
bit 5 TestFailedSinceLastClear See de?nition of action ACTION_ERRM_GetDTCStatusByte
bit 6 TestNotCompletedThisOperationCycle See de?nition of action ACTION_ERRM_GetDTCStatusByte
bit 7 WarningindicatorRequest See de?nition of action ACTION_ERRM_GetDTCStatusByte
Formula section :
tmp_DTCStatusByte = 00h
ACTION_ERRM_GetErrMem(PRM_IDX_ERR, PRM_LV_ERR_MEM)
ACTION_ERRM_GetErr(PRM_IDX_ERR, PRM_LV_ERR)
// Check if failure is in dynamic memory
// if not, respective bits stay on zero
If PRM_LV_ERR_MEM = 1
Then
For IDX_DYN = 0 to CTR_ERR_DYN_NR-1
If DIAG_INST[IDX_DYN] = PRM_IDX_ERR
and LV_ERR_MKD[IDX_DYN] = 0
Then
// Test failed this operation cycle (dynamic part)
bit 1 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = LV_ERR_DC[IDX_DYN]
// Pending DTC
bit 2 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = LV_ERR_PND[IDX_DYN]
// Confirmed DTC
bit 3 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = LV_ERR_CFM[IDX_DYN]
// Warning Indicator requested (MIL & EPCL)
If LV_DC_MAX[IDX_DYN] = 1
and bit 2 of WAL_CONF[PRM_IDX_ERR] = 1
Then // MIL is requested
bit 7 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = 1
Else If PRM_LV_ERR = 1 and
(bit 0 of WAL_CONF[PRM_IDX_ERR] = 1
or bit 1 of WAL_CONF[PRM_IDX_ERR] = 1)
Then
// WAL_1 or WAL_2 is requested
bit 7 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = 1
Endif
Exit for loop
Endif
Endfor
Endif
// Test failed:
// failure status without consideration of initializations at key, reset, ..
bit 0 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = LV_ERR_REC[PRM_IDX_ERR]
// Test failed this operation cycles (static part: for ignition key based DC)
bit 1 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = (bit 1 of tmp_DTCStatusByte)
or LV_ERR_LST_IGK[PRM_IDX_ERR]
// Test failed since last clear:
ACTION_ERRM_GetErrLastClr(PRM_IDX_ERR, PRM_LV_ERR_LST_CLR)

ERRM, UDS communication interface (Appl. Inc.)
Bit 5 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = PRM_LV_ERR_LST_CLR
// Test not completed this operation cycle
ACTION_ERRM_GetEndDiag(PRM_IDX_ERR, PRM_LV_END_DIAG)
bit 6 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = not (PRM_LV_END_DIAG)
// Test not completed since last clear
ACTION_ERRM_GetReady (PRM_IDX_ERR, PRM_LV_Ready)
bit 4 of tmp_DTCStatusByte = [(PRM_LV_ERR_LST_CLR=0) and (PRM_LV_READY=1)]
PRM_DTCStatusByte = tmpDTCStatusByte
35.39.2 DTC Severity calculation
The DTC severity is calculated according the ISO-14229. Here is an extract of the norm.

This part is a generic proposal. It could be updated for project
specific needs
ACTION_ERRM_GetMilRelevant(PRM_Index,PRM_LV_MIL_RLV)
If PRM_LV_MIL_RLV = 1
Then
If CTR_DC_INC[PRM_Index] = CTR_DC_MAX[PRM_Index]
Then
PRM_DTC_Severity = 80h (checkImmediately)
Else
PRM_DTC_Severity = 40h (checkAtNextHalt)
Endif
Else
PRM_DTC_Severity = 20h (maintenanceOnly)
Endif

ERRM, ERRM - Non volatile memory data interface
The detail of the storage depends on the type of memory used and the general availability of memory space
in the different projects. To ensure a time effective storage, the data are not stored in one block, but in several
sub-blocks.
In general the following minimum requirements for ERRM storage must be considered:
? At end of PWL, when all ERRM calculations are done, all ERRM data (including PERM as ?rst channel and
STAT as last channel) must be stored to NVMY.
? At begin of PWL the PERM channel must be stored to NVMY: If the writing of the PERM channel is
not successful, then only those permanent fault codes RAM data, which indicates the permanent fault
codes stored in NVMY, shall be reset.
? If PERM channel is determined as corrupted when reading then it shall be initialized / reset to neutral, the
rest of ERRM data shall remain as they are. If any of ERRM channels (except PERM one) is determined as
corrupted when reading then all ERRM channels shall be initialized / reset to neutral, the PERM channel
shall remain as it is.
Basic ERRM PERM interface to NVMY:
At each storage of ERR_PERM[NC_NR_ERR_PERM] in non volatile memory, ?rst of all, ERR_PERM[NC_NR_ERR_
PERM] is copied in a buffer inside (permanent fault codes mode).
If the storage is completed: the NVMY returns if the writing is erroneous or not.
The content of the writing buffer ( ERR_PERM_WriteBuffer ) and the storage status (writing is erroneous or not)
is updated inside ERRM by call of the callback function from NVMY.
Endif
