35.40.1 Storage of ERRM with EEProm Emulation (Flash)
� General Information
In this chapter the storage handling of PERM and all other ERRM channels with EEProm emulation NVMY
solution is described.
PERM and ERRM data shall be stored only in case of real PWL phase (after IGK_ON). PERM/ERRM data shall
not be stored in ?Short PWL? case after pure wake up (no IGK_ON). This is necessary to reduce the number of
ECME write cycles to the necessary minimum because the maximum number of write cycles is limited due
to HW limitations (?ash for EE simulation). If PERM/ERRM data will be stored or not is controlled by LV_INH_
NVMY_SAVE.
At beginning of PWL:
? only PERM data are stored
? if PWL phase is interrupted by IGK_ON, the storage is continued (at background) and ?nished for the
PERM channel.
? If the writing of the PERM channel is not successful, then the NVMY mirror of permanent failure index
are initialized inside the permanent fault codes module by callback.
In PWL phase, when all PWL lock conditions have been reset except ?NVMY?:
1) PERM storage
? PERM is stored as an independent block by ECME (project con?guration). If PWL phase is interrupted
by IGK_ON, the storage for the current channel is skipped and the storage for all remaining channels will
be canceled.
? if the writing of the PERM channel is not successful, then the NVMY mirror of permanent failure index
are initialized inside the permanent fault codes module by callback.
2) ERRM_PWL storage (along with all NVMY PWL data)
? ERRM block is con?gured as END_PWL, so one checksum for all END_PWL channels is used (either all
are stored or none is stored)!
? all ERRM data are stored along with all other NVMY_PWL data in ECME ?Background Mode?
? after storage of NVMY PWL data is ?nished the PWL lock condition ?NVMY? will be reset
? if PWL phase is interrupted by IGK_ON, the storage for the current channel is skipped and the storage
for all remaining channels will be canceled.

ERRM, ERRM - Non volatile memory data interface
At Restore event (ECU reset):
? if storage of any channel (except PERM one) was not successful (e.g. due to loss of battery voltage
during previous storage), then all data except PERM data are erased (with default NVMY con?guration),
or, if older ERRM data exist in NVMY, ECME will reload them.
? if the writing of the PERM channel is not successful (e.g. due to loss of battery voltage during previous
storage), then only the permanent fault code data (see PERM module) are erased (with default NVMY
con?guration) or, if older PERM data exist in NVMY, ECME will reload them.
In order to keep all in NVMY saved PERM and ERRM data consistent (they shall be from the same driving
cycle) the consistency handling (check of compatibility of PERM and ERRM data) was introduced.

Remark: Due to IGK_ON a new DC (driving cycle) is started during the storage, that?s why a mix of ERRM data
from old and new DC will be stored. Normally after next IGK_OFF a consistent set of ERRM data will be stored.
Only in case of unintended reset (e.g. due to low battery while engine start) these not fully consistent ERRM
data will be read out at beginning of next cycle.

� Function Description
1. The storage of the ERRM data in NVMY block (END_PWL) is done via END_PWL con?guration in ECME
2. The storage of the PERM data as ?rst channel is done via ?on the ?y? con?guration in ECME.
ATTENTION: As PERM channel has to be con?gured as ?on the ?y? channel, the call of the NVMY routine of
PERM has to be done manually. PERM channel is now added directly inside ECME, in order to be in
line with short and long PWL as well as robust against changes in NVMY PWL storage timing.

35.40.3 Consistency check and initialization of ERRM channels
� General Information
In this chapter the consistency check of the ERRM channels are described. It is needed for example in case of
loss of battery voltage between storage of two ERRM channels. In that case the checksum from NVMY would
be correct and the NVMY is not able to detect an error. Therefore a consistency check has to be performed in
order to catch this inconsistency.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At NVMINI event:
In case of at least one (except PERM one) damaged ERRM channel:
Init all ERRM which are NVMY relevant
#these are defined inside their ERRM modules - - among other
things RBM statistics, intermittent memory, history memory,
statistical data, lamp management
ACTION_ERRM_ClcPermanentIniErrm()
#Same strategy in case of clearing of the failure memory
PERM channel - permanent fault code data must be NOT initalized
within this block.
CTR_PWL_FMY_LST = 0
CTR_PWL_FMY = CTR_PWL_PERM_FIRST
# Robustness init, in case of any damaged ERRM channel (except PERM
one) or in case of serial EEPprom used: if only STAT channel
damaged, then in both cases the restore function of STAT won?t
be called and the recalculation of CTR_PWL_FMY is not possible.
In case of damaged PERM channel:
Init PERM channel - permanent fault code data
CTR_PWL_PERM_FIRST = 0
At TO_PWL event:
refer to ACTION_ERRM_HandleNVMYAtToPwl
At EXIT_PWL event (e.g. by KEY_ON):
refer to ACTION_ERRM_HandleNVMYAtExitPwl
At NVMRES event:
Restore the ERRM data

35.40.4 Writing the permanent fault codes to non volatile memory
� General Information
At each storage of ERR_PERM[NC_NR_ERR_PERM] in NVMY, ?rst of all, ERR_PERM[NC_NR_ERR_PERM] is copied
in a buffer; when the storage is completed: the NVMY returns if the writing is erranous or not.
The content of the writing buffer (ERR_PERM_WriteBuffer) and the storage status (writing is erroneous
or not) is updated inside ERRM by call of the action.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: -
Activation: At each storage completed of PERM channel in NVMY via NVMY callback
handling.
Deactivation: -
Recurrence: -
� Function Description
If callback event of permanent fault codes happened AND
storage of PERM channel was successfull
Then
# Read back stored values from Shadow-Writebuffer
PRM_ERR_PERM[0...NC_NR_ERR_PERM-1]= pointer to content of shadow buffer
(accessable via ACTION_ECME_Nvm_Buf_Addr())
PRM_LV_ERR_NVMY_PERM_STOR = 0
Else
PRM_LV_ERR_NVMY_PERM_STOR = 1
For (IDX_PERM=0, IDX_PERM<NC_NR_ERR_PERM, IDX_PERM++)
PRM_ERR_PERM[IDX_PERM] = 0
EndFor
Endif
ACTION_ERRM_ReadNVMYErrPerm(PRM_ERR_PERM[NC_NR_ERR_PERM], PRM_LV_ERR_NVMY_PERM_
STOR)

� Action De?nitions
ACTION_ERRM_GetMilGroupIndex(IN <PRM_IDX_ERR>, OUT <PRM_IDX_ERR_MIL_GRP>) Mode: O
This action is used to know if the failure is representative for MIL group or not.
Parameter Type Hex.Limits Phys.Limits Resol. Unit
PRM_IDX_ERR in 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Failure Index
PRM_IDX_ERR_MIL_GRP out 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Parameter to indicate which failure index is de?ned for MIL group representative (in case of non MIL group, FFFFh is used)
� General Information
For each failure, C_ERR_MIL_GRP[IDX_ERR] de?nes the failure instance IDX_ERR which is ?xed as "group repre-
sentative". Case a failure A is Symptom combined to another B one, its driving cycle counter is managed using
C_ERR_CLAS[B] value.
In case of Symptom Combination unused, C_ERR_MIL_GRP[IDX_ERR] is set of FFFFh (typical value).
Example :
To de?ne the failure TCO_EL_H (coolant temperature sensor failure "circuit high") as Symptom combined to
TCO_PLAUS :
? C_ERR_MIL_GRP[TCO_EL_H] = "TCO_PLAUS" = > TCO_EL_H is using Symptom combination and the
representative Symptom Combination
is TCO_PLAUS. Driving cycle counter of
TCO_EL_H is managed according
C_ERR_CLAS[TCO_PLAUS]

ERRM, Error management (gen)
� 1. Emission calibration selection
Variant coding to select emission level
In order to handle several emissions levels regulations (ULEV2 / EU4 / EU5) with one unique software release,
each variant shall be selected by variant coding (tester communication service). Software will behave accord-
ing selected variant in view of calibration and functional strategies.
For such purpose, few calibrations are de?ned in array format (size : NC_NR_VAR_EMI]
Index of each array is de?ned by IDX_VAR_EMI. With NC_NR_VAR_EMI = 0, this feature isnot used.
Example:
With NC_NR_VAR_EMI = 2, two emission variants are de?ned.
IDX_VAR_EMI can have two values depending on chosen variant:
0: emission variant 0 (e.g. EU5) is active
1: emission variant 1 (e.g. EU4) is active
Calibrations concerned by such feature are :
- C_CONF_MIL
- ID_ERR_CLAS_A_FMT
- C_STATE_READY_OBD_2
- C_STATE_READY_OBD_3
� 2. Warm-up cycle de?nition
Warm Up cycle de?nition depends on type of vehicle :
- combustion engine or hybrid vehicle (LC_DC_EL_VEH = 0)
- electric vehicle (LC_DC_EL_VEH = 1)
Warm Up cycle for combustion engine or hybrid vehicle
The warm-up cycle is de?ned according regulation �1968.2 chapter (c)(37) (CARB) :
?Warm up cycle? means suf?cient vehicle operation such that the coolant temperature has risen by at least 40
degrees Fahrenheit (C_TCO_WUP_INC) from engine starting and reaches a minimum temperature of at least
160 degrees Fahrenheit (140 degrees Fahrenheit for applications with diesel engines) (C_TCO_WUP_THD).
The warm-up cycle detection is enabled only when engine temperature at start is lower than a threshold
C_TCO_ST_MAX_INH_WUP_CYC.
Warm Up cycle for electric vehicle
OBD status information ?Warm Up cycle" (LV_WUP_CYC) is set if the following conditions are ful?lled :
- Cumulated trip length (time since engine start) T_AST_WUP >= C_T_AST_WUP
(customer requirement 600 s)
- Cumulative vehicle operation >= C_VS_THD_WUP for minimum of C_T_VS_WUP
(customer requirement >= 40 km/h (25mph) for at least 300 s)

� 3. OBD fault management
Failure con?rmation strategy
OBD failure con?rmation may be delayed until engine start or ?ready for driving?. For that purpose, LC_ENA_
CFM_OBD_ST = 1. Else, OBD failure con?rmation may occur at engine stop position (hybrid vehicles : electric
machine and combustion engine are both stopped)
Warm-up cycles counter
According regulation �1968.2 chapter (2)(2.4) (CARB), it is allowed to erase a con?rmed fault code after at least
40 warm-up cycles, provided that malfunction has not been detected again and MIL lamp is not illuminated
for that malfunction.
The minimum number of warm-up cycles required to erase a con?rmed fault code is de?ned with C_CTR_
MAX_WUP_CYC. When NLC_CTR_AGI_ENA = 1, failure healing after C_CTR_MAX_WUP_CYC warm-up cycles is
not considered and failure is never healed by warm-up counter strategy.

� 4. Driving cycle de?nition
OBD AK LH 5.0 (German OEMs interpretation of CARB) - Standard
For combustion engines (no hybrid): A driving cycle starts with "ignition on" and ends with the next time
"ignition on" if the engine has reached the ?rst engine start conditions for at least 2 seconds (+/- 1 s) in between.
Engine stops which are not caused by the driver or ECU don?t end the driving cycle.
For hybrids and engines with shutoff strategies, the driving cycle is de?ned as the time between ?ignition on?
and the next time "ignition on" if either the engine has reached the ?rst engine start conditions for at least
2 seconds (+/- 1 s) or condition ready for driving. Engine start conditions shall be equivalent to conventional
power trains (e.g. engine speed and electric motor speed).
CARB de?nition - Regulation
?Driving cycle? consists of engine startup and engine shutoff and includes the period of engine off time up to
the next engine startup.
For vehicles that employ engine shut-off strategies (e.g., engine shut-off at idle), the manufacturer may request
Executive Of?cer approval to use an alternate de?nition for driving cycle (e.g., key on and key off). Executive
Of?cer approval of the alternate de?nition shall be based on equivalence to engine start-up and engine shut-
off signaling the beginning and ending of a single driving event for a conventional vehicle. Engine restarts
following an engine shut-off that has been neither commanded by the vehicle operator nor by the engine
control strategy but caused by an event such as an engine stall may be considered a new driving cycle or a
continuation of the existing driving cycle.
The driving cycle starts with "ignition on" and ends with the next time "ignition on" if the engine has reached
the ?rst engine start conditions for at least 2 seconds (C_T_OBD_QLD parameter) continuously in between.
Engine start is de?ned as the point when engine reaches a speed 150 rpm (C_N_ST_OBD) below the normal
warmed-up idle speed (C_N_WUP_IS_OBD).
In addition, two strategies may be activated in order to end driving cycle after a too long trip based on mileage
(LC_DIST_DC_END_ENA, C_DIST_MAX_DC) or time (LC_T_DC_END_ENA, LC_T_DC_END_ENA ) criteria. For Heavy
Duty applications LC_DIST_DC_END_ENA = 1 may be used. As regard, light duty applications, LC_DIST_DC_END_
ENA = 0 is the typical value.
Regarding, PID $1F, two options may exist according customer strategy. Then, post-operating phase could be
counted or not depending on LC_INC_PID_1F_PWL calibration value.

� 5. Similar conditions
For some diagnostics Similar Driving Conditions function is required to manage OBD fault statuses : Mis?re,
Fuel Trim and Fuel System diagnostics.
Similar conditions are additional conditions based on engine speed, load and warm-up status to which are
needed to manage some diagnostics into failure memory. It?s required for Mis?re and Fuel system failure only,
according to CARB 1968.2 rules. For EOBD application it?s not required to use this feature.
It is possible to inhibit Similar Conditions functionality by LC_ENA_SCDN = 0.
Note : whatever the value of LC_ENA_SCDN, when NLC_ENA_SCDN = 0, it is impossible to enable similar condi-
tions.
Similar driving conditions
Similar Driving Conditions window is a rectangular area de?ned as follow :
- Engine speed within plus/minus 375 rpm of the original fault occurrence
- Engine load within plus/minus 20% of the original fault occurrence
- Engine warm-up conditions are identical to original fault occurrence (hot or cold)
Dimensions of the rectangular window are 2 x C_N_SCDN_EQU and 2 x C_LOAD_SCDN_EQU. Its center is de-
?ned by engine speed and engine load measured at fault detection.
Optionally, similar driving condition are enhanced with the MPI/DI injection split factor.
Then, in addition to previous dimensions, MPI/DI split factor shall be within plus/minus 20% of the original fault
occurrence
Fault management and similar driving conditions
According OBD AK LH 5.0, similar conditions shall not be used for fault con?rmation but shall be
for fault healing. With LC_ENA_CFM_WOUT_SCDN = 1 such principle is applied, else encountering of similar
conditions is required to con?rm faults too.

� 6. Lamp management
Lamp calibration
All lamp-con?gurations MIL_0, MIL_1 (if two emission variants are available) and WAL_1, WAL_2
(if warning lamps are available, e.g. safety lamp) are managed with C_CONF_xx:
Bit0
0= Lamp can be switched ON
1= Lamp always OFF (switched on only by tester-tool)
Bit1
0= Lamp can be switched ON by external request (e.g. by Tester-Tool, or Gearbox)
1= External lamp request always OFF
Bit2 (xx = MIL[0/1])
0= Management at Mis?re is OFF (MIL is only Blinking)
1= Management at Mis?re is ON (Blinking only for a calibratable time)
Bit2 (xx = WAL_1/2)
0= Link to MIL activation if WAL_1/2 is requested is OFF
1= MIL will be also switched to ON if WAL_1/2 is requested
Bit3
0= Pre-drive check ON
1= Pre-drive check OFF
Pre-drive check
The minimum duration of the pre-drive check (e.g. needed at quick starts) can be set with
C_T_MIN_PRDR_CHK.
The maximum time of pre-drive check duration with engine stopped can be limited to
C_T_MIL_READY_1 + C_T_MIL_READY_2 when LC_T_MAX_PRDR_CHK_ENA = 1
For vehicles with a MIL blinking feature for readiness status displaying during pre-drive check (see
NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK), C_T_MIL_READY_1 and C_T_MIL_READY_2 must be de?ned:
- C_T_MIL_READY_1: delay to start MIL blinking for readiness display during pre-drive check
- C_T_MIL_READY_2: MIL blinking duration for readiness displaying during pre-drive check
MIL blinking at Mis?re
If bit2 of C_CONF_MIL is set and Mis?re with cylinder cut off is active, the MIL is only blinking for
C_T_INH_IV_MIS, afterwards the MIL in ON.
Lamp management calculation
In order to enable a faster calculation of lamp management, mainly to ensure a rapid lamp illumination after
reset, before the ?rst 500 ms recurrence, LC_LAMP_UPD_CLC_ENA may be set
to 1. This feature may be used when transmitting lamp status to dashboard, toward vehicle
network, and when 500 ms recurrence is not compatible with network messages constraints.
Warning lamps illumination
With LC_DC_MAX_WAL, warning lamps WAL 1 & 2 may be illuminated when LV_ERR[IDX_ERR] = 1 or LV_DC_
MAX[IDX_DYN] = 1.

� 7. Diagnostic interface (Anti-bounce/Filters/Initializations)
Diagnostic initialization
Every diagnostic can be con?gured by C_ABC_INI_TYP_xx
bit 0: No init at Reset - Typical value 0 : init on Reset
bit 1: No init at Key Transition - Typical value 0 : init on IGK
bit 2: No init on DC - Typical value 0 : init on DC (1 ini only if |ABC|=MAX)
bit 3: Fast restart (MEM_INI) - Typical value 0 : not fast restart
bit 4: Failure frozen until key Off (MEM) - Typical value 0 : no freeze on failure
bit 5: Reset ABC if lost CDN - Typical value 0 : no reset on lost condition
bit 6: External initialization behaviour during RST/KEY_ON enabled - Typical value 0 (1:allowed, 0:locked)
bit 7: Failure locked, no ERRM input - Typical value 0 : monitor activated
Possible values:
0h = STD_INI or MPL_STD_INI / 3h = STD / 14h = MEM / 1Ch = MEM_INI / 3Ch = STC / 4h =
STD_INI_DC_MAX (special case for diagnostics activated in the same time as engine starts)
Generic anti-bounce ?lter mechanism
- C_ABC_INC_(16)_xx, to increment the counter when a symptom is detected
- C_ABC_MAX_(16)_xx, to indicate the maximum value of the anti-bounce counter.
- C_ABC_DEC_(16)_xx, to decrement the anti-bounce counter when no symptom is detected.
Remark
- Increment should be always calibrated >1
- C_ABC_DEC_xx is optional, depending on the diagnostic function de?nition

� 8. Failure Classes
Four types of failure classes are available and may be calibrated:
? C_ERR_CLAS[IDX_ERR] =>Calibration for MIL / WAL / Scan Tool management
? C_ERR_CLAS_2[IDX_ERR] =>Calibration of Readiness group ($01/41)
? C_ERR_RBM_CLAS[IDX_RBM] =>Calibration of IUMPR group (RBM $09)
? C_ERR_MIL_GRP[IDX_ERR] =>Calibration of MIL-grouping
8.1 Calibration of MIL / WAL / Scan Tool management
The failure class number is a byte divided in two subclasses named Class B (de?ned by the most
signi?cant bits) and Class A (de?ned by the less signi?cant bits).

8.3 Calibration of In-Use Monitoring Performance Ratio (IUPR or RBM) group
Description:
For each diagnostic connected to rate-based monitoring function (IUMPR), a calibratable group
must be de?ned with C_ERR_RBM_CLAS[IDX_RBM]. Therefore, NC_NR_DIAG_RBM calibrations
are de?ned.
The 4 less signi?cant bits (less signi?cant nibble) of C_ERR_RBM_CLAS[IDX_RBM] are used to
de?ne the group of each diagnostic.
For diesel applications, the 4 most signi?cant bits (most signi?cant nibble) of
C_ERR_RBM_CLAS[IDX_RBM] are used to de?ne if diagnostic shall use the mileage criteria or
not.
For some monitors, 500 miles cumulative distance of vehicle operation experienced since the last
time the denominator of monitor was incremented is required. Therefore, in addition to
numerators/denominators a distance must be computed for such diagnostics requiring mileage
criteria.

8.4 Calibration of MIL-grouping
Each failure can be combined with other failures in order to activate the MIL-grouping, thus the second/third
error of the group is con?rmed for $02/$3/$0A even the last failure occurs the ?rst time.
C_ERR_MIL_GRP[IDX_ERR] de?nes the failure instance IDX_ERR which is ?xed as "group representative".
In case of MIL group unused, C_ERR_MIL_GRP[IDX_ERR] is set of FFFFh (typical value).
Example.
Three failures are combined to one MIL group: TPS_AD_1 / TPS_AD_2 / TPS_AD_3 (US Application)
C_ERR_MIL_GRP[TPS_AD_1] = TPS_AD_1 (Group-Master)
C_ERR_MIL_GRP[TPS_AD_2] = TPS_AD_1 (Group-Member)
C_ERR_MIL_GRP[TPS_AD_3] = TPS_AD_1 (Group-Member)
Results:
In the ?rst DC, TPS_AD_1 is pending.
In the second DC, TPS_AD_2 occurs = >MIL is on
Mode $02/$03 reports TPS_AD_2.
Remark: C_ERR_MIL_GRP[IDX_ERR] calibration is produced only when symptom grouping function is enabled
(NLC_SYM_GRP_ENA = 1)

9. Clearing of failure memory / permanent failure memory / history memory / Intermittent failure array
/ IUMP - ratios
For development conveniences, it is often useful to clear ERRM data:
LC_ERR_FMY_CLR 0 ->1 = >Failure memory can be erased
LC_ERR_FMY_HIS_CLR 0 ->1 = >History memory can be erased
LC_ERR_INTM_CLR 0 ->1 = >Intermittent failure array can be erased
LC_ERR_INTM_CLR 0 ->1 = >Permanent failure memory can be erased
LC_RBM_CLR 0 ->1 = >RBM (IUMPR numerators/denominators) can be reset to 0
LC_CLR_CTR_CLR_FMY 0 ->1 =>Number of FMY clear events since last ECU ?ashing reset
Additional for the Intermittent failure array a clearing process can be managed at the system Event
Reset (RST), LV_IGK 0->1 and Failure memory clearing depending on the calibration C_ERR_INTM_CLR_INI.
Description of C_ERR_INTM_CLR_INI:
bit 0 = 1 =>array is cleared at ECU reset
bit 1 = 1 =>array is cleared at LV_IGK 0->1 transition
bit 2 = 1 =>array is cleared when Error management is cleared
Remark:
These transitions are calculated in a 1s task. =>Clearing process is executed within 1s
Warning : after reset of failure memory, LC_ERR_FMY_CLR must be reset to 0, nominal value of
this calibration.

10.1 Diagnostic Trouble Code
For each diagnosis instance IDX_ERR, different DTC?s can be assigned (CUS/INFO optional):
- C_ERR_DTC_OBD[IDX_ERR] for the OBD DTC according SAE J2012
- C_ERR_DTC_CUS[IDX_ERR] for the customer speci?c DTC (optional, if NC_NR_DTC_FMT = 1)

according ISO14229

10.2 DTCs displaying options for Mode $03 $07 or $0A
For DTCs displaying on Scan Tool or customer tool, two options exists.
When several symptoms calibrated with identical values are logged, Mode $03 $07 or $0A report :
- one DTC value when LC_ENA_MPL_DTC_DISP = 0
- all identical DTCs when LC_ENA_MPL_DTC_DISP = 1 (for US Application)

TCO_EL_H symptom is calibrated with ERR_DTC_OBD[TCO_EL_H] = 0118h (P0118)
TCO_EL_L symptom is calibrated with ERR_DTC_OBD[TCO_EL_L] = 0118h (P0118)
TCO_EL_OL symptom is calibrated with ERR_DTC_OBD[TCO_EL_OL] = 0118h (P0118)
If, due to a faulty connector, the three symptoms are logged as pending (Mode $07), scan tool will display :

Readiness classes
According regulation the readiness status must be reported in Mode$01/PID1 according ISO 15031-5 / SAE
J1979.
The supported monitors are calibrated with C_STATE_READY_OBD[VAR_EMI]:
The supported non-continuous monitors are calibrated with C_STATE_READY_OBD_x:

Bit 1 - Fuel system monitoring supported
Bit 2 - Comprehensive component monitoring supported
Bit 3 - Catalyst / NMHC Catalyst monitoring

Bit 6 - Secondary air system / Boost pressure monitoring
Bit 7 - reserved
Bit 8 - Oxygen sensor / Exhaust Gas sensor monitoring
Bit 9 - Oxygen sensor heater / PM Filter Heater monitoring
Bit 10 - EGR system monitoring
Bit 11 - Private group
x is the emission variant index.
Example:
Typical value for US application with VVT/no SAIR system is: 72F (Hex) / 0111 0010 1111 (Binary)
With C_STATE_READY_OBD_CMPL_OBD_x it?s possible to set the readiness status for
continuous diagnostics (comprehensive components, mis?re and fuel system monitors) directly to
ready (bit = 1).

� 14. Rate-Based Monitoring (IUMPR) - Denominator calculation
General Denominator
For the for Rate-Based Monitoring statistics calculation, ARB has de?ned standardized vehicle
operations (RBM Driving Cycle), which must be met to increment IUMPR denominator counters.
File: 7EQ02U04.00A
10149Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
ERRM, Error management (gen)
Cold Start Denominator
The individual monitor condition established for evaporative system denominator calculation (see
�1968.2 - 4.3.2, section D) is de?ned by the Cold Start Denominator (also used for some
temperature rationality monitors).
Denominator with Mileage criteria
For some monitors (Diesel NMHC converting catalyst, Diesel RCAT NOX reduction catalyst), 500
miles cumulative distance of vehicle operation experienced since the last time the denominator of
monitor was incremented is required.
For diesel monitors requiring mileage criteria, only strategy 1 (LC_DIST_DC_RBM_STGY = 1)
should be applied.
Calibration of individual Denominator condition
For each diagnostic with in-use performance ratio calculation C_ENA_IND_CDN_RBM[IDX_RBM]calibration is
used to de?ne if additional individual conditions to increment denominator are required.
? when C_ENA_IND_CDN_RBM[IDX_RBM] = x0000000b, the only condition required to increment the
denominator is the general denominator
? when C_ENA_IND_CDN_RBM[IDX_RBM] <>x0000000b, bits set to 1 indicate which corresponding con-
dition is required, in addition to the general denominator.
? when set, the bit 7 of C_ENA_IND_CDN_RBM[IDX_RBM] is used to indicate if additional conditions may be
calculated by diagnostic itself to increment individual denominator.
Note that for diagnostics designed without additional conditions, bit 7 of C_ENA_IND_CDN_RBM is pre-calibrated
by SW tooling as ready-only, whereas other bits may be calibrated. Possible range for calibration is therefore
[0...127].
Then, additional conditions are met when both conditions handled by diagnostic and conditions computed in
the current module are gathered together. For diagnostics connected by calibration to rate-based monitoring,
this bit shall remain to 0 to disable the diagnostic reporting.

� 16. Permanent fault code
Standardized vehicle operation for permanent fault code
Subsequent to a clearing of the failure memory (e.g. Mode $04), the permanent fault code is erased if the
diagnostic that caused the permanent fault code to be stored has been fully executed and determined the
malfunction is no longer present and special vehicle operation has been encountered (Permanent fault code
driving cycle).
Permanent fault code consistency check
Calibration to enable the permanent data consistency check of ERRM NVMY channel, to prevent data to
become irremovable due to sudden power supply loss.
LC_ENA_PERM_ERRM_CHK = 1 when permanent fault code functionality is required and Mode $0A active (US
market).

� 17. Bench mode manager
The bench mode is useful to set/reset failure manually for development purposes. The availability of this func-
tionality depends on the con?guration NLC_BENCH_MODE and NC_NR_MAX_IDX_BENCH (maximum number
of diagnostic managed by bench mode). With LC_ABC_BENCH = 1 the bench mode is activated.
Important note:It is NOT recommended to have the bench mode activated for the serial production.
Step 1: De?ne diagnostic instance (symptom) to apply bench mode
C_IDX_ERR_BENCH[xx..yy] = NC_IDX_ERR_xx : diag. instance xx is managed by bench mode,
e.g.
C_IDX_ERR_BENCH[1] = TCO_EL_H
C_IDX_ERR_BENCH[2] = TCO_EL_L
Step 2: De?ne diagnostic result (passed/failed) for the symptom
C_STATE_ERR_BENCH[1] = 1 (PASS) : the failure is reset for the diagnostic instance
=>LV_ERR[XX] = 0 LV_END_DIAG[XX] = 1
C_STATE_ERR_BENCH[1] = 2 (FAIL): the failure is set for the diagnostic instance
=>LV_ERR[XX] = 1 LV_END_DIAG[XX] = 1
C_STATE_ERR_BENCH[1] = 0 (NO_EVE): the bench mode is disabled for the diagnostic instance
Process to deactivate the bench mode:
To disable the bench mode it is necessary to set LC_ABC_BENCH = 0 then to force an ignition key transition
(on ->off ->on) or a reset.
Erase all failures by bench mode:
To erase all failures (LV_ERR_xx = 0) and to inhibit all diagnostics requests, for all diagnostic instances not
managed by the bench mode, it?s necessary to set LC_ABC_BENCH_LOCK_OK = 1 and then to force an ignition
key transition (on ->off ->on).

� 18. Communication interface
Error management locked by tester
Error management can be locked by tester. To avoid a locked error management in case of loss
communication a security mechanism is implemented =>within C_T_FMY_ERR_LOCK a new
con?rmation must be received from Tester to keep FMY locked.
Any transition from 0 to 1 of LC_CLR_CTR_CLR_FMY will reset the counter counting the number of failure
memory clear events experienced by ECU since last ECU reprogramming (NVMY erasement).
Example:
Tester recurrence = 300ms =>C_T_FMY_ERR_LOCK = 300ms + 100ms = 400ms
DTC available mask for UDS service $19 02
The DTCStatusAvailabilityMask (Default = FF) can be calibrated by C_ERR_DTC_AVL_MASK,
e.g. the Tester is not able to read all bits from DTCStatus, in this case set bit to 0.
C_CTR_MAX_IDX_SCAN is the maximum number of diagnostics scanned in one recurrence, in order to prepare
answer to UDS services $19-01 $19-02 and $19-13.
Default value for C_CTR_MAX_IDX_SCAN is 20 but this value shall be tuned according CPU load available on
project.
Priority of FUEL diagnostic for freeze frame
When C_ENA_FRF_FUEL_PRI =
? ?FUEL? : both sub-groups FUEL_CLC and FUEL_CMPL have the highest priority for the selection of failure
which gives out the freeze frame to Mode $02.
? ?FUEL_CLC? : highest priority is given to diagnostics belonging to FUEL_CLC
? ?FUEL_CMPL? : highest priority is given to diagnostics belonging to FUEL_CMPL

--- Page 74 ---

## Function
The primary function of this Simulink diagram fragment is to define and manage a set of diagnostic filter algorithms within an automotive embedded system, explicitly labeled as "ERRM. Diagnostic filter algorithms". It illustrates a modular and hierarchical architecture for processing various diagnostic conditions. Each `ACTION_ERRM_FilterX` block represents an instance of a counter-based filtering algorithm, designed to evaluate the persistence of fault conditions (e.g., signal validity) over time, and output a robust diagnostic result (Pass/Fail) while smoothing out transient signal fluctuations. The overall system aggregates these individual filter outcomes to produce consolidated diagnostic states.

## Inputs
The diagram's top-level inputs are implicitly the "ActionExport" ports from the `ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterX` blocks. These blocks serve as the definitional or triggering points for the respective diagnostic filter actions, implying that they receive conditions or events that initiate the filtering process.

*   **`ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterAbc X.1`**: Triggers or defines the `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbc` filter.
*   **`ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterAbc16 X.4`**: Triggers or defines the `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbc16` filter.
*   **`ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterStc X.2`**: Triggers or defines the `ACTION_ERRM_FilterStc` filter.
*   **`ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterAbcEnd X.3`**: Triggers or defines the `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbcEnd` filter.
*   **`ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterConf X.5`**: Triggers or defines the `ACTION_ERRM_FilterConf` filter, which also depends on other filter states.

(Implicitly, based on the detailed description of `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbc`, each individual filter algorithm takes a "Signal Status" (e.g., OK/Not OK) as its primary input, along with configurable parameters like increment/decrement values (`PRM_ABC_INC`, `PRM_ABC_DEC`) and thresholds (`PRM_ABC_MAX`).)

## Outputs
The diagram explicitly shows several "Action" outputs, representing the results or callable instances of the diagnostic filter algorithms:

*   **`ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbc`** (identified by bubble 1): Output of the `ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterAbc` logic.
*   **`ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbc16`** (identified by bubble 5): Output of the `ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterAbc16` logic.
*   **`ACTION_ERRM_FilterStc`** (identified by bubble 2): Output of the `ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterStc` logic.
*   **`ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbcEnd`** (identified by bubble 3): Output of the `ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterAbcEnd` logic.
*   **`ACTION_ERRM_FilterConf`** (identified by bubble 4): This is a consolidated output, potentially representing a final or higher-level diagnostic state derived from the results of `ACTION_ERRM_FilterStc`, `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbcEnd`, and the logic defined by `ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterConf`.

(Implicitly, from the detailed description of `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbc`, each filter's output includes a "FilterResult" (e.g., NO_EVE, INTM sporadic, PASS, FAIL) and a binary pass/fail flag (LV_ERRR[XX] Fail/Pass)).

## Logic Flow
The diagram outlines a structured approach to diagnostic algorithm execution:

1.  **Action Definition and Triggering**: Each `ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterX` block (e.g., `ACTIONDEF_ERRM_FilterAbc X.1`) serves as a module that defines or triggers a specific diagnostic "Action". The "ActionExport" port signifies that these are callable functions or event-driven executions.

2.  **Individual Filter Operation**: Each `ACTION_ERRM_FilterX` (e.g., `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbc`, `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbc16`, `ACTION_ERRM_FilterStc`, `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbcEnd`) implements a dedicated counter-based filter algorithm, as detailed for `ACTION_ERRM_FilterAbc`:

## Function

This Simulink diagram implements a diagnostic filter algorithm, typical for an automotive system's Electronic Control Unit (ECU). Its primary function is to process a raw input signal (`PRM_ABC_in`) related to a condition (e.g., fault detection) through a stateful counter (`PRM_ABC`). Based on the presence or absence of the condition and the counter's current value, it determines and outputs a filtered, debounced diagnostic state (`PRM_STATE_FIL`) and the current value of the internal counter (`PRM_ABC_out`). The algorithm manages the counter's incrementing and decrementing, clamping its value within defined limits, and uses its state to transition between different diagnostic states.

## Inputs

*   **PRM_ABC_INC (1):** A parameter representing the increment value for the `PRM_ABC` counter when the 'no fault' condition is active. This is likely a positive integer.
*   **PRM_ABC_in (3):** The primary input signal, which is a boolean or integer. Based on the counter's update logic, it is interpreted as `true` (non-zero) for "fault condition present" and `false` (zero) for "no fault condition present".
*   **PRM_ABC_MAX (2):** A parameter representing the maximum allowed value for the `PRM_ABC` counter. It is used to clamp the counter's upper limit.
*   **127:** A constant threshold value used for comparison against `PRM_ABC` to determine specific diagnostic states (e.g., `FAIL` or `INTM`).
*   **0:** A constant value used for comparison against `PRM_ABC` to determine specific diagnostic states (e.g., `NO_EVE` or `INC`), and as a lower bound for `PRM_ABC` during incrementing.

## Outputs

*   **PRM_ABC_out (1):** The current value of the internal filter counter `PRM_ABC`. This output provides the live state of the debounce/filter mechanism.
*   **PRM_STATE_FIL (2):** The filtered diagnostic state, represented by an integer value. This output indicates the consolidated health or fault status based on the filter logic. The possible states are:
    *   `0`: `NO_EVE` (No Event / Fully Cleared)
    *   `2`: `FAIL` (Confirmed Failure)
    *   `3`: `INTM` (Intermediate State / Pending Failure)
    *   `4`: `INC` (Incrementing / Clearing State)

## Logic Flow

The system operates in discrete time steps, managing the `PRM_ABC` counter and determining the `PRM_STATE_FIL` based on inputs and the counter's value.

**1. `PRM_ABC` Counter Management (Left Side of Diagram):**
    *   The `PRM_ABC` variable functions as a stateful counter (implicitly a Unit Delay, with its output being `PRM_ABC_current` and its input being `PRM_ABC_next`).
    *   **Conditional Update:** The update logic for `PRM_ABC` (its next value) depends on the `PRM_ABC_in` signal:
        *   **If `PRM_ABC_in` is non-zero (Fault Condition Present):**
            *   The `PRM_ABC` counter is decremented by 1 (`PRM_ABC_current - 1`).
            *   This decremented value is then clamped to be at most `PRM_ABC_MAX` (using a `min` block), preventing it from exceeding the maximum limit.
        *   **If `PRM_ABC_in` is zero (No Fault Condition Present):**
            *   The `PRM_ABC` counter is incremented by `PRM_ABC_INC` (`PRM_ABC_current + PRM_ABC_INC`).
            *   This incremented value is then clamped between `0` (using a `max` block) and `PRM_ABC_MAX` (using a `min` block).

*   **If `PRM_ABC_in` is zero (No Fault Condition Present):**
            *   The `PRM_ABC` counter is incremented by `PRM_ABC_INC` (`PRM_ABC_current + PRM_ABC_INC`).
            *   This incremented value is then clamped between `0` (using a `max` block) and `PRM_ABC_MAX` (using a `min` block).
    *   The result of this conditional calculation becomes the new value for `PRM_ABC` for the next time step. The `PRM_ABC_out` output provides this current `PRM_ABC` value.

    **Interpretation of `PRM_ABC` ("No Fault" Counter / "Health Score"):**
    *   This logic implies `PRM_ABC` represents a "No Fault" duration or a "Good Health" confidence level.
    *   When a fault is detected (`PRM_ABC_in` is TRUE), this "No Fault" counter decreases.
    *   When no fault is detected (`PRM_ABC_in` is FALSE), this "No Fault" counter increases.

**2. `PRM_STATE_FIL` (Filtered Diagnostic State) Determination (Right Side of Diagram):**
    The `PRM_STATE_FIL` output is determined by a nested conditional logic that acts as a state machine, based on `PRM_ABC_in` and the current `PRM_ABC` value:

    *   **Main Condition: `PRM_ABC_in` (Is a Fault Detected?)**
        *   **If `PRM_ABC_in` is non-zero (FAULT DETECTED):**
            *   The system then checks the current value of the `PRM_ABC` ("No Fault" counter):
                *   **If `PRM_ABC >= 127`:** `PRM_STATE_FIL` is set to `FAIL` (2). This state implies that a fault is detected, *and* the "No Fault" counter is still at a high value. This could indicate a critical or unexpected failure mode, where the system's previous "health" (high `PRM_ABC`) seems to contradict the newly detected fault.
                *   **Else (`PRM_ABC < 127`):** `PRM_STATE_FIL` is set to `INTM` (3). This state implies a fault is detected, and the "No Fault" counter has decreased below the `FAIL` threshold, indicating an intermediate or pending fault condition.
        *   **If `PRM_ABC_in` is zero (NO FAULT DETECTED):**
            *   The system then checks the current value of the `PRM_ABC` ("No Fault" counter):
                *   **If `PRM_ABC <= 0`:** `PRM_STATE_FIL` is set to `NO_EVE` (0). This state indicates that no fault is detected, and the "No Fault" counter has reached its lower bound, implying the system is fully healthy or has completely recovered from any previous issues.
                *   **Else (`PRM_ABC > 0`):** `PRM_STATE_FIL` is set to `INC` (4). This state indicates no fault is detected, and the "No Fault" counter is actively increasing towards its maximum (or full confidence) value, indicating a healthy and recovering state.

This logic effectively filters a raw fault input over time, using `PRM_ABC` as a temporal buffer or "health score" to produce a more stable and meaningful diagnostic state output.

    *   `FAIL` (2): Indicates a confirmed failure.
    *   `INTM` (3): Indicates an intermediate failure state.
    *   `PASS` (1): Indicates that the system has passed the diagnostic check (error cleared).
    *   `NO_EVE` (0): Indicates no specific event (neither failure nor pass condition met, or no active error).

## Logic Flow

The filter operates in two primary modes, selected based on the overall system's assessment of whether an error has been detected or not (e.g., via a `PRM_ABC_TYP` parameter as suggested in 35.4.4).

### 1. Case: An error has been detected (Figure 35.4.13)

This mode is active when an error condition is currently active or being monitored for persistence.

*   **Counter Update (`PRM_ABC`):**
    1.  The previous value of `PRM_ABC` is retrieved.
    2.  It is incremented by `PRM_ABC_INC` and `PRM_ABC_in` (`PRM_ABC_prev + PRM_ABC_INC + PRM_ABC_in`).
    3.  This sum is then limited by `PRM_ABC_MAX` using a `min` block (`min(sum, PRM_ABC_MAX)`).
    4.  The result becomes the new `PRM_ABC` value and is output as `PRM_ABC_out`. This effectively implements a saturating discrete-time integrator that counts up.

*   **Filter State Determination (`PRM_STATE_FIL`):**
    *   A primary `If` block evaluates the condition: `(PRM_ABC == PRM_ABC_MAX)` AND `(fcn_call() is TRUE)`.
        *   **If TRUE (Cond_if branch):** The counter has reached its maximum, and the error condition (`fcn_call()`) is true.

This effectively implements a saturating discrete-time integrator that counts up.

*   **Filter State Determination (`PRM_STATE_FIL`):**
    *   A primary `If` block evaluates the condition: `(PRM_ABC == PRM_ABC_MAX)` AND `(fcn_call() is TRUE)`.
        *   **If TRUE (Cond_if branch):** The counter has reached its maximum, and the error condition (`fcn_call()`) is true. `PRM_STATE_FIL` is set to `FAIL` (2).
        *   **If FALSE (Else branch):** The flow proceeds to a nested `If` block, which evaluates `fcn_call()`.
            *   **If `fcn_call()` is TRUE (Cond_if branch):** The error condition is present, but the counter has not yet reached its maximum. `PRM_STATE_FIL` is set to `INTM` (3).
            *   **If `fcn_call()` is FALSE (Else branch):** The error condition is not currently present. `PRM_STATE_FIL` is set to `NO_EVE` (0).
    *   All branches merge to output `PRM_STATE_FIL`.

### 2. Case: No error has been detected (Figure 35.4.14)

This mode is active when the system is operating without a detected error, or actively attempting to clear a previously detected error.

*   **Counter Update (`PRM_ABC`):**
    1.  The previous value of `PRM_ABC` is retrieved.
    2.  It is decremented by `PRM_ABC_DEC` and `PRM_ABC_in` (`PRM_ABC_prev - PRM_ABC_DEC - PRM_ABC_in`).
    3.  This result is then limited by `0` using a `max` block (`max(result, 0)`).
    4.  The result becomes the new `PRM_ABC` value and is output as `PRM_ABC_out`. This implements a saturating discrete-time integrator that counts down.

*   **Filter State Determination (`PRM_STATE_FIL`):**
    *   A primary `If` block evaluates the condition: `(PRM_ABC == 0)` AND `(fcn_call() is TRUE)`. In this context, for "PASS" to be logical, `fcn_call()` must signify the *absence* of an error condition.
        *   **If TRUE (Cond_if branch):** The counter has successfully reached zero, AND the "no error" condition (`fcn_call()`) is true. `PRM_STATE_FIL` is set to `PASS` (1).
        *   **If FALSE (Else branch):** This means either `PRM_ABC` is not zero, or the "no error" condition (`fcn_call()`) is false (i.e., an error is detected). `PRM_STATE_FIL` is set to `NO_EVE` (0).
    *   All branches merge to output `PRM_STATE_FIL`.

Upon activation, the internal monitor cycle counter (`PRM_FRC`) and failure counter (`PRM_TCC`) are updated based on their respective input signals (`PRM_FRC_in`, `PRM_TCC_in`).
2.  **Monitor Cycle Counting**:
    *   When the `Signal status` (the condition being monitored) indicates a "Not OK" (NOK) state, the `Monitor cycle counter` (`PRM_FRC`) begins to increment with each monitoring interval.

3.  **Failure Counting**:
    *   Simultaneously, when the `Signal status` is "NOK", the `Failure Counter` (`PRM_TCC`) increments. This counter quantifies the occurrences or duration of the "NOK" condition within the monitoring window.
    *   The `Failure Counter` is reset by a "Reset Failure Counter" event, typically when the diagnostic condition passes or upon explicit reset commands.

This typically involves a sufficient period of "OK" status.

They describe the functionality of an "ERRM. Bench mode manager."

## Function

The primary function of these diagrams, collectively part of the "ERRM (Error Reaction Management) Bench mode manager," is to control and manipulate error statuses when the system is operating in a diagnostic or test environment known as "bench mode." This manager allows engineers to:

1.  **Trigger actions** based on changes in critical error-related states or parameters.
2.  **Force specific errors to a 'PASS' or benign state** (e.g., overriding a detected fault) at a given index within a dedicated bench mode error storage. This is crucial for isolating components, testing recovery mechanisms, or simulating specific operational scenarios without actual fault conditions.
3.  **Deactivate or clear these forced 'PASS' states**, effectively removing the bench mode override for an error and allowing its true status to be reported or acted upon by the main error management system.

This functionality ensures controlled testing and validation of error handling strategies.

## Inputs

The key inputs across these three diagrams are:

*   **`ACTION_FARM_TriggerOnEvent`**: An event or signal indicating a trigger from the Fault Reaction Management (FARM) system to initiate an action based on state changes. (Figure 35.8.18)
*   **`PRM_IDX`**: A parameter index used to identify which parameter's state is being evaluated or acted upon. (Figure 35.8.18)
*   **`PRM_STATE_OLD`**: The previous state of the parameter identified by `PRM_IDX`. (Figure 35.8.18)
*   **`PRM_STATE_NEW`**: The current (new) state of the parameter identified by `PRM_IDX`. (Figure 35.8.18)
*   **`ACTION_ERRM_Pass`**: An action event or signal that requests the forcing of a specific error to a 'PASS' state in bench mode. (Figure 35.8.19)
*   **`IDX_ERR`**: The index of the specific error within the error array whose bench mode override state is to be modified or accessed. (Figures 35.8.19 and 35.8.20)
*   **Constant `1`**: A value used to set an error's bench mode override state to 'PASS'. (Figure 35.8.19)
*   **Constant `0`**: A value used to clear or remove an error's bench mode override state. (Figure 35.8.20)

## Outputs

The primary "output" of these diagrams is the modification of an internal persistent data store:

*   **`LV_ERR_BENCH`**: This is an internal "Action Store" (a type of Data Store Memory or persistent variable) that holds an array or vector of values. Each element in this array corresponds to an error index, storing its current bench mode override status (e.g., `1` for forced 'PASS', `0` for cleared/no override). The diagrams' logic manipulates this store.

Internal signals that facilitate the logic but are not top-level outputs include:

## Logic Flow

The logic flow is divided into three distinct operations, each represented by a figure:

### 1. Event Triggering for FARM (Figure 35.8.18)

This diagram illustrates a mechanism for triggering events or actions based on state transitions relevant to Fault Reaction Management (FARM):
*   **Step 1 (Event Input):** An input signal or event, `ACTION_FARM_TriggerOnEvent`, activates this logic path, signaling that an event related to FARM needs processing.
*   **Step 2 (State Monitoring):** At the same time, `PRM_IDX` (a parameter identifier), `PRM_STATE_OLD` (its previous state), and `PRM_STATE_NEW` (its current state) are provided. This indicates that a state change for a particular parameter has occurred.
*   **Step 3 (Action Execution):** The "ActionImport" block suggests that these inputs (especially the `ACTION_FARM_TriggerOnEvent`) are utilized by the internal subsystem (represented by the black box and `f()`) to execute specific actions or propagate the event further within the bench mode manager, reacting to the detected state transition.

### 2. Forcing Error to 'PASS' in Bench Mode (Figure 35.8.19)

This logic forces a specific error to a 'PASS' state (i.e., overriding any actual fault) when the system is in bench mode:
*   **Step 1 (Action Trigger):** The `ACTION_ERRM_Pass` input signal (or an implied event triggering this logic via `f()`) initiates the operation to set an error to 'PASS'.
*   **Step 2 (Error Identification):** The `IDX_ERR` input provides the index of the specific error that needs to be overridden. This index is passed as `PRM_IDX_ERR` to the `Selln` (select input) port of the array manipulation block.
*   **Step 3 (Read Current State):** The current contents of the `LV_ERR_BENCH` (Action Store), which holds all bench mode error override states, are read as `Vec_In` by the array block.
*   **Step 4 (Set 'PASS' Value):** A constant value of `1` is fed into the `In` port of the array block. This `1` represents the 'PASS' or benign state for the error.
*   **Step 5 (Indexed Update):** The `Array[NC_NR_MAX_IDX_ERR]` block performs an indexed write operation. It takes `Vec_In`, updates the element at the index specified by `Selln` (`PRM_IDX_ERR`) with the value `In` (`1`), and outputs the modified vector as `Vec_Out`.
*   **Step 6 (Store Update):** The `Vec_Out` (the updated vector of bench mode error overrides) is then written back into the `LV_ERR_BENCH` (Action Store), thereby permanently setting the specified error to 'PASS' for bench mode purposes.

### 3. Deactivating Bench Mode Override for an Error (Figure 35.8.20)

This logic clears or deactivates the bench mode override for a specific error, allowing its true status to be observed:
*   **Step 1 (Action Trigger):** An implicit trigger (e.g., "no_eve" as mentioned in the title, or an event processed by `f()`) initiates the deactivation process.
*   **Step 2 (Error Identification):** The `IDX_ERR` input specifies the index of the error for which the bench mode override should be removed. This index is passed as `PRM_IDX_ERR` to the `Selln` port of the array manipulation block.
*   **Step 3 (Read Current State):** The current contents of `LV_ERR_BENCH` (Action Store) are read as `Vec_In` by the array block.
*   **Step 4 (Set 'CLEARED' Value):** A constant value of `0` is fed into the `In` port of the array block. This `0` signifies that the error's bench mode override is cleared or removed.
*   **Step 5 (Indexed Update):** The `Array[NC_NR_MAX_IDX_ERR]` block performs an indexed write operation.

*   **Step 4 (Set 'CLEARED' Value):** A constant value of `0` is fed into the `In` port of the array block. This `0` signifies that the error's bench mode override is cleared or removed.
*   **Step 5 (Indexed Update):** The `Array[NC_NR_MAX_IDX_ERR]` block performs an indexed write operation. It updates the element at the index specified by `Selln` (`PRM_IDX_ERR`) within `Vec_In` with the value `In` (`0`), and outputs the modified vector as `Vec_Out`.
*   **Step 6 (Store Update):** The `Vec_Out` (the updated vector) is then written back into the `LV_ERR_BENCH` (Action Store), effectively removing the bench mode 'PASS' override for the given error index.

## Function
The primary function of the main diagram (Figure 35.8.30, titled "ERRM. Bench mode manager") is to manage and override specific error states within an automotive system during a "bench mode" testing scenario. It iterates through a predefined list of error indices and their desired states, triggering specific actions (Pass, Fail, or Bench Mode Off) for each error based on configuration and an active bench mode condition. ## Logic Flow

The diagram operates within a "For Iterator" loop, processing one error configuration at a time. Let `i` represent the current iteration index provided by the "For Iterator".

It is not a standard Simulink block diagram, but a representation of behavioral logic that can be modeled in Simulink. Therefore, I will proceed with the analysis.

## Function
The primary function of this state machine is to manage the operational states of an automotive lamp system. It orchestrates the transitions between the lamps being completely off, performing a pre-drive self-check for diagnostic purposes, and entering a normal operational mode. This management involves responding to system resets, ignition cycles, various configuration settings, engine status (like stalling), and internal timing mechanisms related to the pre-drive check.

## Inputs
The state machine is driven by a combination of system events, configuration parameters, and real-time status signals:

*   **RST system event:** A hard system reset signal, typically indicating ECU power-up or a global reset.
*   **LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD (Boolean):** A crucial command signal related to lamp activation/deactivation. Its exact interpretation (e.g., `1` for active/on request, `0` for inactive/off request) is context-dependent and presents some ambiguity in the diagram.
*   **C_CONF_XXX (Configuration Bits):**
    *   `bit 0 of C_CONF_XXX`: A configuration setting, likely to enable or disable the pre-drive check.
    *   `bit 3 of C_CONF_XXX`: Another configuration setting, influencing transitions.
*   **LV_OBD_ES (Boolean):** OBD (On-Board Diagnostics) Engine Stopped status, likely indicating an engine stall or engine being off.
*   **NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK (Configuration/Status Bits):** Non-Configured Lamp Pre-Drive Check status or setting.
    *   `bit 0 of NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK`
    *   `bit 1 of NC_LAMP_PRDR_CHK`
*   **LV_LAMP_PRDR_CHK_STALL (Boolean):** A status flag related to the pre-drive check, possibly indicating its completion or a specific internal event.
*   **T_PRDR_CHK[m] (Timer Value):** A timer representing the elapsed time for the pre-drive check, with `m` representing an index (e.g., 0, 1, 2 for MIL_1, WAL_1, WAL_2).

*   **T_PRDR_CHK[m] (Timer Value):** A timer representing the elapsed time for the pre-drive check, with `m` representing an index (e.g., 0, 1, 2 for MIL_1, WAL_1, WAL_2).
*   **C_T_MIN_PRDR_CHK (Constant):** A threshold constant for the minimum required time for the pre-drive check.
*   **C_DLY_READY_1, C_DLY_READY_2 (Constants):** Delay constants used in calculating readiness thresholds.
*   **LC_T_MAX_PRDR_CHK_ENA (Boolean):** Enable flag for a maximum pre-drive check timer.
*   **LV_OBD_ST (Boolean):** General OBD status.
*   **LV_LAMP_PRDR_CHK_ERU (Boolean):** Lamp Pre-Drive Check Error Unit status.

## Outputs
The primary outputs of this state machine are its current active state, which implicitly dictates the behavior of the automotive lamps:

*   **LAMP_OFF state:** Lamps are commanded to be switched off.
*   **PREDRIVE_CHECK state:** Lamps are activated for a diagnostic self-check sequence (e.g., flashing to check bulb functionality). Readiness status indicators (like the MIL – Malfunction Indicator Lamp) might blink to show the check is incomplete.
*   **NORMAL state:** Lamps operate normally; the pre-drive check has been successfully completed.

Implicitly, the state machine controls lower-level functions such as:
*   Sending commands to turn lamps on or off.
*   Executing specific lamp flash patterns during diagnostics.
*   Controlling instrument cluster indicators related to lamp readiness or faults.

## Logic Flow

The state machine operates with three primary states: `LAMP_OFF`, `PREDRIVE_CHECK`, and `NORMAL`.

1.  **System Initialization (Entry to LAMP_OFF):**
    *   The state machine always starts in the `LAMP_OFF` state following a `RST system event` (e.g., ECU boot-up).
    *   In `LAMP_OFF`, all lamps are switched off.

2.  **Activating the System from LAMP_OFF:**
    *   **To PREDRIVE_CHECK:** If `LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD = 1` (interpreted as "command to activate lamps" or "ignition on"), the system transitions to `PREDRIVE_CHECK`. This typically happens when the ignition is turned on, and the pre-drive check is configured to run.
    *   **To NORMAL (Bypass):** If `(bit 0 of C_CONF_XXX = 1) OR (LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD = 1)`, the system can transition directly to `NORMAL`. This occurs if the pre-drive check is configured to be skipped (`bit 0 of C_CONF_XXX = 1`) and the lamp system is commanded to activate (`LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD = 1`). If `bit 0 of C_CONF_XXX` is `0`, then `LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD = 1` would lead to `PREDRIVE_CHECK`, suggesting priority or ordered evaluation of transitions.

3.  **Completing the Pre-Drive Check (PREDRIVE_CHECK to NORMAL):**
    *   The `PREDRIVE_CHECK` state activates a visual diagnosis of lamps. The transition to `NORMAL` can occur via several paths:
        *   **Path 1 (Normal Completion):** If `(LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD = 0 AND LV_OBD_ST = 1 AND T_PRDR_CHK[m] >= C_T_MIN_PRDR_CHK)`. This suggests the check completes successfully after a minimum time, with positive OBD status, and no explicit command to turn lamps off.
        *   **Path 2 (Engine Stopped Completion):** If `(LV_LAMP_OFF_CMD = 0 AND LV_OBD_ES = 1 AND T_PRDR_CHK[m] >= (C_DLY_READY_1 + C_DLY_READY_2) AND LC_T_MAX_PRDR_CHK_ENA = 1)`.
